I’ve got twelve episodes of my Rebels re-watch to go, and I also hope to re-watch The Mandalorian ‘Chapter 13: The Jedi’ & The Book of Boba Fett ‘Chapter 6: From the Desert Comes a Stranger’. Aug 9, 2023

A pair of highlighted passages from recommended recent newsletters:

our political and social structures, the philosophies and ways we’ve educated ourselves aren’t up to the task of truly, ethically handling many of our contemporary technologies or sciences of the quantum echelon

Craig Mod: Roden #082 — ‘Sandwiches, Oppenheimer, Shooting Film’

As much as A.I. has gotten better at making human-like art, creation is arguably the easiest step in the process of cultural formation. Every day thousands if not millions of people propose new ideas and practices, but only a tiny sliver ever win attention, attract adherents, or take on collective meanings. Ironically, generative A.I. has emerged just as we’re already emeshed in a human-created crisis of cultural overproduction. Most human-created art today fails to take on social value.

W. David Marx: Culture: An Owner’s Manual — ‘Our Natural Human Defenses Against A.I. Culture’

Aug 9, 2023

I’ve just finished Barbara Kingsolver’s superb novel Demon Copperhead (2022), winner of both the Pulitzer Prize and the Women’s Prize for Fiction (and yet, curiously not nominated for the Booker Prize). The book was my pick for this summer’s instalment of my annual read-along project, Sipped Ink, and as such, most of what I have to say about it has made its way into the weekly newsletters over the last six weeks. I will say that it’s absolutely proven to be one of those novels that I’m simultaneously sad to finish and glad to have read. Heartbreaking, deeply empathetic, and told in the voice of one the most endearing narrators I’ve encountered in a long while. 📚

Aug 8, 2023

In an effort to consolidate some of my online footprint, I’m winding up use of the service I’ve previously employed for bookmarking images, and I’ll likely post a few here more frequently — for my future reference more than anything else.

Aug 7, 2023

Patricia Lockwood on David Foster Wallace, for the London Review of Books 📚

As he writes in one of his most typically tall-tale essays, ‘Derivative Sport in Tornado Alley’, he was, as a ‘near-great’ junior tennis player, at his very best in bad conditions. In fiction, he creates them; he serves himself sleet, hail, sun in the eye, all for the chance to play through them.

Aug 7, 2023

A few snaps from yesterday’s trip to Bath: decent coffee; incredible pizza; a nice walk down along the canal. Happening past a building once home to Jane Austen was a wonderful surprise!

Aug 4, 2023

For the time being at least, my experiment with Threads is over. It was kind of fun being over on Meta’s microblogging platform for the first couple of weeks, whilst folks were busy figuring out how things worked. But even then, there was such a dense presence of brands, influencers, and celebrities, that things felt a bit creepy. When I wrote up my initial impressions, I tried to put this (not insignificant negative) in balance:

This is the promise and the peril of the centralised platform: everyone’s here (but that includes the try-hard brands, and the thirsty celebrities). So, yes, it already feels a little icky, and the advertisers aren’t even there yet. But — as predicted — the new platform immediately allowed me to reconnected with some folks who never would have made their way to Mastodon.

At least in my experience, however, virtually all those folks posted one or two exploratory messages in week one, and then stopped posting. Whether or not they’re still logging into Threads and lurking, or whether they’re amongst the reported decline in engaged users is hard to tell, but either way, the balance quickly swung away from ‘people I want to keep up with’ and towards ‘people Meta think I should be interested in’.

The recent addition of the ‘Following’ tab helped a little. But, the design decision to have the app switch back to the algorithmic feed every time you open it, betrays the direction that Meta want to move this thing in. I’m going to keep an eye on things — especially since the continued, precipitous decline of Twitter / X will likely send more people over there — and I’m still eager to see what happens as and when Threads federates. For now, you can catch me on Mastodon and via email.

Aug 4, 2023

Additions to the queue on #newmusicfriday — a quieter week, but maybe there’s something here. 🎵

Aug 2, 2023

Another Wes Anderson note for the day, since I just watched The Afterparty s2e4. Say what you will about the specifics of Anderson’s filmmaking style, but imagine having crafted a bespoke look and tone unique enough to be parodied. Other episodes of The Afterparty have co-opted the styles of whole eras (regency period), and genres (romcom; noir; heist), but s4e2 is borrowing solely from Anderson. How many other filmmakers could you do this for and expect wide recognition from the audience of a half hour comedy? Hitchcock? Miyazaki? Tarantino maybe? Even then, I think it would read to many as a broader adoption of the genres in which they operate. 🍿📺

Aug 2, 2023

Ever since I saw Asteroid City a few weeks ago, I’ve been pondering a re-watch of Wes Anderson’s whole back catalogue. Reading this piece by Khoi Vinh has suggested a new frame through which to do so:

Anderson is a child at heart, of course, and that shows up countless times in his films, whether it’s in his scripts or his stage dressing or his picture book-like cinematography. However, the flip side of this youthful empathy is that Anderson is essentially lost when it comes to adult characters and, by extension, stories about adults. For me, this is the weakness that sabotages films like The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou and the abysmal The Darjeeling Limited, which are populated with nonsensical, schematized characters that talk at one another but never truly interact.

My personal ranking of Anderson’s movies, as it stands right now, looks like this:

1 — The Royal Tenenbaums
2 — Asteroid City
3 — The Grand Budapest Hotel
4 — The French Dispatch
5 — Rushmore
6 — Moonrise Kingdom
7 — Isle of Dogs
8 — Fantastic Mr. Fox
9 — The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou
10 — The Darjeeling Limited
11 — Bottle Rocket

I’m not sure I’d call The Darjeeling Limited ‘abysmal’ as Vinh does, but it’s one of a few that I’ve only seen once. I recall coming away from it very disappointed, and I don’t recall now what it was about the film that didn’t work for me. I find it interesting that Vinh offers a reason for the relative weakness of both Darjeeling & Life Aquatic that I’d not considered before — it might be fun to go back through Anderson’s oeuvre with this in mind. (FWIW Bottle Rocket is another I’ve seen only once, and which felt to me like Anderson’s Pablo Honey: by no means bad, but containing only glimpses of future greatness.) 🍿

Aug 2, 2023

I love this illustration by Christoph Niemann, from A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader (2019). 🎨

Aug 1, 2023

New today from a friend’s fuzz-rock band, Desire Lines. The ‘Everything is Fine’ EP is out now on Bandcamp, and major streaming platforms. 🎵

Aug 1, 2023

This morning the longlist was announced for this year’s Booker Prize, and it is not what I had expected. Perhaps my perspective has been mildly warped by the fact that I’m currently leading a group read-along of Demon Copperhead, but — having won both the Pulitzer Prize & the Women’s Prize for Fiction — it felt like Barbara Kingsolver’s novel was a lock for the list. Not only that, I had also anticipated spots amongst the thirteen longlisted novels1 for Eleanor Catton’s Birnam Wood; Catherine Lacy’s Biography of X; Salman Rushdie’s Victory City; and possibly John Banville’s The Singularities. So, all told, I went 0/5 on these predictions!

The vast majority of these titles are new to me, and I’ve read none of them. I’m not committed to reading the whole list — as I did a couple of years ago — but I’ll certainly be looking more closely at a few of these titles in the coming months. 📚

  1. the so-called ‘Booker Dozen’ ↩︎

Top 5 Weezer Songs

Jul 19, 2023

You can blame this one on Brett Seybert — who in turn is blaming it on Luke O’Neil —  but I’ll never pass up a chance to talk Weezer, so here we go.

To begin, let me say that I’m calling this the ‘Buddy Holly’ Memorial List, for two reasons: a) the band’s most famous song1 is too easy a pick; b) it’s unbeatable and I need to cheat to get it on this list somehow. So, just for the record, ‘Buddy Holly’ is a perfect song; the guitar lick at 2:09 would be on my list of top 5 moments in recorded music2. It was my introduction to the band, at age 14, in my high school computer room. The inclusion of the (all-time great) music video on the Windows 95 install CD remains both inexplicable, and sort of magical in my mind. So yes, ‘Buddy Holly’ is not on this list, but… you know 😉

Jamie (1993)

Only fitting then, that my first pick3 is the b-side from the ‘Buddy Holly’ single. Holy smokes! Has there ever been a better a-side / b-side CD single?4 Rivers Cuomo is famously prolific, and he has an ear for melody that is second-to-none. I can’t imagine any other artists dashing off a quirky, sweet paean to their band’s lawyer. That opening feedback, the rumbling riff, the heartfelt lyrics, chant-along bridge, croon-along chorus. Weird and wonderful.

You Gave Your Love to Me Softly (1995)

Maybe the world’s sweetest 100mph rock ballad? A riff that burns like a lit fuse; another extremely ‘join in at full volume’ chorus; a squealer of a solo… all packed in to less than two minutes. Guaranteed to stick in my head for hours every time I listen to it.

I Just Threw Out the Love of My Dreams (1996)

A sad / sweet synth rock masterpiece with one of my absolute favourite vocal melodies. Rachel Haden is flawless, and the bridge, with its duet vocal, is perfect. Add in Rivers somehow shredding a synth, and building the whole thing to a soaring finish. Unbeatable.

Sheila Can Do It (1996 / 2020)

How about an album track? And a recent one too, just to prove I’m not an insufferable hipster. For me, this is easily the highlight of Weezer’s last 15 years. That it’s core is essentially unchanged from the 1996 demo version probably says something, but I adore this sing-song vocal melody and playful riff. The bridge and chorus are unimpeachable.

Listen Up (2001)

OK, I’m an insufferable hipster. This is probably one of my favourite songs ever, by any artist, and it’s a demo from the peak of Rivers’ hyper-productive period around the Green album when every b-side and off-cut was better than what was ending up on other bands’ albums. The dynamics of this song are a marvel to me, and perfectly capture a seemingly effortless knack for imbuing simple pop melodies with aching beauty. So few artists can pull off that trick with any consistency: among them Lennon & McCartney; Brian Wilson; Rivers Cuomo. If you don’t happen to have the 2001 demo (or BBC live session) lying around, here’s a YouTube version — enjoy! 🎵

  1. Is this still true? Do people think of ‘Hash Pipe’ and / or ‘Beverly Hills’ now, when you mention Weezer? If so, shame. ↩︎

  2. FWIW, the only thing I know right now would beat it, is the piano part at 1:22 – 2:18 on Nina Simone’s ‘My Baby Just Cares For Me’. ↩︎

  3. These are in chronological order. ↩︎

  4. Nirvana’s ‘Lithium’ / ‘Been a Son’ combo, or The White Stripes’ one-two punch ‘Fell In Love With a Girl’ / ‘Let’s Shake Hands’ are the only couple that come to mind that could maybe compete. ↩︎

Jul 14, 2023

Added to the queue on #newmusicfriday — I’m most excited for the new Palehound, and the Claud debut. 🎵

Jul 12, 2023

In the last couple of years, since spinning up a Gaming division, Netflix has quietly built an enviable portfolio of titles available (at no extra charge) to subscribers. I’m writing this today because the long-awaited Oxenfree II: Lost Signals has just been released. The developers behind this title (and the original Oxenfree), Night School, were one of the first studios to be acquired by Netflix1, signalling that they were serious about games. I had a great time with the original game when it was released in 2016, and this week I picked up a month of Netflix mainly to play the sequel. Such is the company’s strategy, presumably: to add to their content release schedule not just new TV shows, but must-play games — two parallel tracks via which to gain (and keep) subscribers.

Consider your options if you want to play the new game right now:

• Steam (PC & Mac): £13.49 (25% launch sale, down from £17.99)
• Nintendo Switch: £13.49 (25% launch sale, down from £17.99)
• PlayStation: £14.24 (25% launch sale, down from £18.99)

Or, you can pick up a month of Netflix (from £4.99), and play the game on your iOS or Android device. Plus, you get to finish season three of Emily in Paris!

Here’s a list of a few other games on the service that I would recommend:

• Terra Nil — city-builder / strategy
• Kentucky Route Zero — truly one-of-a-kind point & click adventure
• Immortality — one of my absolute favourite games of 2022
• Spiritfarer — sweet, easygoing management-style game
• Into the Breach — space-set turn-based strategy
• Moonlighter — shop management

And of course, the original Oxenfree — spooky adventure with excellent writing.

I’m not affiliated with Netflix in any way, nor would I accept money from anyone to advertise anything, ever2. But, I do believe in sharing cool things when I find them, and in my experience a lot of people with active Netflix subscriptions don’t know that they could also be playing excellent games without spending an extra penny. 🕹️

  1. in September of 2021 ↩︎

  2. I was actually close to writing a post today about how gross it is to see all the SEO clickbait pieces popping up shilling for Prime Day — yuk! ↩︎

How High are the Garden Walls?

Jul 11, 2023

This afternoon, UK-based tech company Nothing unveiled their second smartphone: Nothing Phone (2).

Just as with the original model, I love the way this thing looks, and I admire the design ethos behind it: to make tech innovative and fun again, in an age when iteration on established design languages has become the necessary, safe bet for the entrenched market leaders. Oh, it’s also significantly cheaper than an iPhone. Here are the prices at which some flagship devices start:

• iPhone 14: £849
• iPhone 14 Pro: £1,099
• Google Pixel 7: £599
• Google Pixel 7 Pro: £849
• Nothing Phone (2): £579

I have been an iPhone user since 2011’s iPhone 4S. Over that decade-plus — in which I’ve owned four different models — Apple has worked to ensure that the iPhone has increasingly become the centre of a whole ecosystem of devices and services. The upshot of this strategy (and, indeed, the purpose of it), is that there are significant obstacles for anyone considering a move away from Apple’s phone. As an experiment, I thought I’d do some thinking about what it would mean for me to make the switch.

As a starting point, let’s consider each of the apps currently on my iPhone’s Home Screen:

Fantastical — no Android version is available, but I’m sure there are plenty of calendar apps that would make a fine substitute. However, I would then need to figure out what calendar apps to use on iPad and Mac. At present Fantastical is syncing the iCloud calendars associated with my Apple ID, so I might even need to find a new solution for that.

Weather — not a problem; I’m sure there are good Android weather apps.

Apple Music — there actually is an Android version of Apple’s music service, so I wouldn’t need to make a switch.

Pocket Casts — this one’s easy, as there’s an Android version.

Reminders — again, there are certainly acceptable substitutes for this in the Play Store, but one of my main uses of Reminders is for shopping lists shared with my partner. It works seamlessly because our Apple IDs are associated as a family. Getting the same functionality elsewhere would be relatively easy, but would require asking my partner to download a different app — annoying.

Things — no Android version is available, and that’s a significant issue. I’ve used Cultured Code’s task manager to pretty much run my life since January 20101. It’s an essential part of how I think about organising things, and I use it everywhere: Mac, iPad, & Apple Watch, but primarily iPhone. Moving away from it would be tricky. My second choice — OmniFocus — also doesn’t have an Android version. I’d have to resort to something like Todoist, which would also incur a paid subscription (unlike Things).

Photos — another strong argument for iCloud’s flawless syncing between devices. I’ve been using these things long enough to remember when every photo I took on my phone didn’t automatically appear on all my other devices. But I’m absolutely spoiled by it now, and I don’t want to go back to the days of using middle-man services (eg. syncing to Google Photos, and bridging that to iCloud?) to make sure everything’s available everywhere.

HEY — another easy one: there’s an Android version of my email client.

Messages — ah, the blue bubble vs green bubble dilemma! Amongst friends and family, iMessage is by far my most commonly used messaging platform. Yes, between WhatsApp, Signal, Telegram, & SMS, there are plenty of other options, but the inconvenience of a move away from iMessage isn’t to be underestimated.

Arc — not a huge loss at present, and perhaps The Browser Company will eventually bring this to Android.

Day One — another cross-platform win: an Android version of this journalling app is available.

Ivory — there’s no Android version of my preferred Mastodon client, and indeed the options look very limited. I’d probably have to switch back to the official app, which is fine, but not a patch on Ivory.

Matter — my read-it-later service of choice doesn’t have an Android app, so I’d have to switch away from it to an alternative, like Instapaper, Pocket, or Readwise. I don’t do a lot of the actual reading on iPhone though2, so perhaps I could figure out an alternative method of saving items into Matter on the phone, one option being via email.

Micro.blog — a first class Android version of this blogging application is available!

MusicBox — Marcos Tanaka’s music tracking app has become an important part of my listening experience. The fact that no Android version is available would put a major kink in my daily work towards compiling my end of year list.

Reeder — Similar to Matter (above), my feed-reader of choice (since 2009) is also not available on Android. Again, most of the actual reading gets done elsewhere (iPad & Mac), but I’m not discounting the annoyance of having one device missing from that setup.

Sonos — no issues here: the controller for my home audio system is available on Android.

Threads — Meta’s new microblogging platform is by no means an essential part of my digital life, and surely headed to Android in the near future3.

Safari — I like Safari’s privacy-first approach, but I don’t use any of its syncing features (largely because I use Arc as my browser of choice on Mac). Switching to Firefox or something similar on Android wouldn’t be a major pain point.

1Password — luckily my preferred password manager is available everywhere, otherwise this would have been a deal-breaker.

Bear — I’m not married to one particular note-taking application, and I could find something that would work across platforms; perhaps even something with a web / browser version, which would be nice.

Tot — this simple scratchpad is an excellent example of a little application that I use all the time, and which relies entirely upon instant iCloud syncing. I could live without it, but I’d prefer not to!

Looking past the first page, the other stumbling blocks that I can foresee are largely tied to Apple’s own software & services.

• I use FaceTime with family, all of whom could be persuaded to use a platform agnostic alternative, but why should they change their setups for me?
• I use Apple Fitness+ quite a bit, and replacements a) tend to be more expensive, & b) won’t integrate perfectly with my Apple Watch.
• Contacts and Wallet both have native Android allegories, but that would mean managing data in both places: eg. adding or updating a contact on both iOS and Android.
• There are a lot of little ecosystem touches that would break if I had a non-Apple phone: eg. using the phone keyboard, and auto-filling passwords on Apple TV (much easier than navigating an onscreen keyboard with a remote); setting alarms (and choosing music for them) on my HomePod. In both cases I could pull out the iPad each time, but it’s not ideal.
• Not a huge deal, but I also have a case, a MagSafe Wallet, and a MagSafe charger, all of which are highly likely to be compatible with the next iPhone, and are all incompatible with non-Apple options

In short, switching away from iPhone to an Android device would incur a dozen or so penalties ranging from irksome to genuinely annoying. The penalties for staying with iPhone, of course, are twofold:
• No choice as to which operating system you use: you just have what Apple gives you. iOS 17 looks just fine, and has some neat additions, but it is clearly another iteration (and a relatively modest one) on the same design that has persisted since iOS 7 debuted a decade ago. Variety is one of Android’s selling points, and Nothing’s OS (for example) has a distinct look that feels genuinely new.
• A ~£300 premium on each upgrade. As mentioned, I’ve had four iPhones in 12 years, or an upgrade roughly every three years. If the difference between an iPhone and a perfectly capable Android device is £300 each time, that adds up.

One of the reasons I have mixed feelings about all of this, is that I’m the same person who was, not so long ago4, espousing the virtues of not tying oneself into centralised social platforms — of operating independent of any one company’s choices over your experience. And yet here I am lamenting the fact that I’ve voluntarily accrued enough Apple hardware, software, and services, that it would be a pain to break free of them. Yes, of course I appreciate on a daily basis how well all of the components of Apple’s ecosystem work together. But I’m not going to pretend there isn’t a downside, and it comes in the form of lock-in.

  1. I have receipts! ↩︎

  2. That’s reserved largely for the iPad. ↩︎

  3. possibly before they launch a web version!? ↩︎

  4. and not for the first time ↩︎

Two-way Mirrors at the Mall

Jul 7, 2023

I forget where now, but one of the most insightful characterisations of centralised social networks that I’ve encountered, is the idea that a few companies tricked everyone into hanging out at the mall. There’s arguably a flaw in the premise of the oft-quoted idea of a singular ‘digital town square for the world’, but if you were to picture a truly social space at that magnitude, it likely wouldn’t have billboards strewn throughout it. The conversations wouldn’t be monopolised by attention-seeking celebrities. And you certainly wouldn’t invite weirdly anthropomorphised incarnations of innumerable brands to join the party.

All of these things were normalised over years of Twitter & Instagram’s dominance of the social media sphere. Spaces that were ostensibly for people to share their experiences and have conversations, came to include — and arguably to be characterised by — the contributions of others who had alternative motives: commonly to garner attention, and/or to sell something. Instead of communication, these platforms became about broadcast.

After 24 hours playing with Meta’s new microblogging platform — Threads — I’m struck by the extent to which, for all the tsuris in the social media space of late, this established paradigm persists. The platform only has an algorithmically-generated Home feed at present1, and whilst this will likely change, it currently plays as a very open admission from Meta that this isn’t designed as a purely social platform. Like latter day Twitter before it — and like its visual-first sister platform, Instagram — Threads is already a place where, yes, you can share your experiences, and socialise with friends, but you do so whilst surrounded by people who eagerly want your attention and your money. This is the promise and the peril of the centralised platform: everyone’s here (but that includes the try-hard brands, and the thirsty celebrities). So, yes, it already feels a little icky, and the advertisers aren’t even there yet. But — as predicted —  the new platform immediately allowed me to reconnected with some folks who never would have made their way to Mastodon. The colossal power of Instagram’s established social graph did its thing, and 48 million Threads accounts were activated in the first ~24 hours. By most estimates, that’s something like four times the size of every combined Mastodon instance, on day one!

Whether by design or circumstance, Threads’ much-lauded ActivityPub integration isn’t available at launch. At present it is very much a walled-garden proudly professing its ambitions of federation.2 But, overnight, it has become one of the largest entities committed to using the protocol3, and its eventual federation will have consequences for the ActivityPub ecosystem that I don’t think are entirely clear at present. In my experience, reception to the idea on Mastodon has been mixed. Some server admins have pledged to de-federate Threads as soon as it integrates with the protocol; others (including the admin of my server) have a more balanced view. There have been enough questions floating around, that Mastodon-founder / lead developer Eugen Rochko published some notes, seeking to allay fears about Meta’s ability to track Mastodon users, and push adverts to Mastodon servers etc. His conclusion is this:

We have been advocating for interoperability between platforms for years. The biggest hurdle to users switching platforms when those platforms become exploitative is the lock-in of the social graph, the fact that switching platforms means abandoning everyone you know and who knows you. The fact that large platforms are adopting ActivityPub is not only validation of the movement towards decentralized social media, but a path forward for people locked into these platforms to switch to better providers. Which in turn, puts pressure on such platforms to provide better, less exploitative services. This is a clear victory for our cause, hopefully one of many to come.

Whilst there are many unknowns about how all this plays out, I think there’s a good chance that the advent of Threads will redound to the benefit of the social web writ large. Advocates of open protocols like ActivityPub should be optimistic about the arrival of a platform that is already clearly on a path to mass adoption. Whether it’s in weeks’ or months’ time, there will soon be millions more accounts available to follow, almost certainly including people whose posts you will be interested in, but whom would not otherwise have joined a compatible platform. But the best part is, you won’t need to step foot in the mall to follow them. Whatever the Threads experience ultimately becomes, thanks to ActivityPub integration, the option will exist to follow Threads accounts without having to engage with an algorithmically-generated Home feed full of brands and celebrities, without ever having to see an advert, and without giving the surveillance capitalism vampires any more of your data.

Personally, I intend to keep playing around with Threads for now. Likely as soon as it’s possible, however, I’ll switch to following Threads users via Mastodon. It will be interesting to see how easy or difficult Meta make it for Threads users to find and follow non-Threads sources publishing via ActivityPub. That barrier, whilst it’ll almost certainly be bidirectional, may well involve jumping through some cumbersome hoops not-so-subtly designed to keep people on Meta’s platform. I think I’ll be OK with that. If it leads to a kind of two-way mirror effect, where I can follow Threads users’ posts, but it’s harder for them to find mine… well, that’s arguably a win-win.

  1. ie. there is no option to see only posts from accounts you follow ↩︎

  2. In this respect (as in others) it’s very similar to Bluesky in its current state. ↩︎

  3. Eclipsed only by Tumblr, which reportedly has ~500 million blogs, and is also intending to adopt ActivityPub. ↩︎

Jul 7, 2023

A few albums added to the queue on #newmusicfriday 🎵

Jul 6, 2023

I’m hearing the verb “to bagel” used more in Wimbledon commentary this year, meaning to beat an opponent in a set, without losing a game.

In principle it’s quite fun, but it undermines my favourite — though likely apocryphal — explanation for where the term “Love” comes from in tennis: that it’s a malapropism of the French, “l’œuf”: the egg.

🥯🥚🎾

Jul 6, 2023

Hey, are you on Splooter? Did you start a Bomblo account?1 Social media in the era of Twitter’s (ongoing) collapse is truly wild. Me? I have accounts all over the place: Mastodon (as I’ve mentioned before), but also Bluesky, Cohost, T2, Post… and probably more that I’m forgetting. There’s life out there, to varying degrees, and it’s been fun keeping an eye on how things are evolving.

I’ll always keep my own site; it’s too important to the way I feel about the web for me not to have a spot that’s all my own, and subject to no on else’s decision making. No adverts, no cookies, no analytics, and full control over everything I publish. I’d encourage anyone who values what they’re posting online to think about adopting the POSSE mindset: ‘Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere’.

But the social web has its place too, and right now I feel a little as though I’m still looking for a perfect fit.

• Twitter is increasingly a far-right cesspool, and its server architecture seems to be actively on fire.

• My impression of Bluesky has been that it seems chock full of people trying desperately to be funny all the time, which can be exhausting.

• I dig my Mastodon experience, but it’s super niche: mainly people talking about open-source projects, blogging, and the fediverse.

Today, Meta launched their microblogging platform: Threads, and it feels like it has a genuine chance at mass adoption. Leveraging users' already established Instagram social graph gives it a significant jump start. It’s super early, and the v1 released a few hours ago is missing features that may be considered basic (eg. a timeline of accounts you’re following; a browser-based interface; hashtags; availability in the EU!), but it feels like there’s a chance it could provide a place for people to just post about brunch again.

Put another way: a lot of the family, friends, and accounts I previously followed on Twitter were never going to make the jump to Mastodon, but the majority of them already have Instagram accounts, which puts them a click away from Threads. I expect to see a lot of them there fairly soon. If you’re also there, say hi!

  1. Please note, these are not real services (yet), as far as I know. ↩︎

Jul 2, 2023

Newslettering godfather Craig Mod is currently running a limited time pop-up — BASIE!BOP!JAMAICA! — chronicling his visits to several jazz kissa1 in northern Japan. As with everything he publishes, the mix of detail-oriented observation, humane context, and thoughtful rumination is pitch perfect. Here’s a clipping from the latest issue:

Mizuyama tells me how he listens to records: Twenty times, he says standing in the shadows, sipping his fourth whiskey on the rocks, toking his hand-rolled cigarettes. That’s my minimum. Even if I hate the record, I listen to it twenty times. Really listen. Try to understand it. Try to understand what I don’t like about it if I don’t like it. Try to get, truly, what those musicians were saying.

[…]

He says, Look — music doesn’t change. The music on the album doesn’t change. You change. So if you don’t like it today, maybe you’ll like it tomorrow. The onus, he’s saying, is on the listener to reach across the aisle, to consider maybe they got it wrong, to push and pull on the scope of their taste like wet dough until you at least understand, if not love, the art.

I also love Mod’s photo of Mizuyama Kazutsugu’s kissa, Jazz Spot Leaf

Photo by Craig Mod

  1. coffeehouses / cafés specialising in playing jazz from their large vinyl collections ↩︎

Jul 2, 2023

We’re now half way through the year, and it’s tempting to pull together a list of my favourite 2023 records to date… but I think I’ll save that until the end of year list. Instead, here are my favourite ten album covers from the first six months of the year.1

10. Superviolet — Infinite Spring

I’m not 100% sure about the typeface here, though it’s not distracting. I just love the skyscape — which reminds me of long Icelandic summer sunsets — and the use of the moon as a kind of punctuation mark.

9. Mandy, Indiana — I’ve Seen a Way

At once busy and static — I like the ways in which the sunlight, and the water, bring life to the squared off forms of the walls.

8. Nappy Nina — Mourning Due

A little on the nose perhaps, given the artist’s name, but this makes me smile every time I see it. I appreciate the effort put into the elegant execution of a simple visual joke.

7. Albert Hammond Jr. — Melodies on Hiatus

I’ve been a sucker for Helvetica for a long, long time, and it hasn’t stopped working for me yet. I like the balance of bold feature typeface and an abstract background.

6. Militarie Gun — Life Under the Gun

I like the painterly qualities of this, and the choice to make it a direct overhead vantage. With the human figures’ shadows, it has something of Muse’s Absolution (2003) about it.2

5. Unknown Mortal Orchestra — V

I have no idea of the story behind this photo, but the combination of an active, arresting image with the simple rendering of the album’s title works superbly.

4. Kelela — Raven

Kelela has a history of strikingly posed record covers, but I think this simple black & white composition is perhaps the best yet. You can almost feel the subtle, living motion in it.

3. Lia Kohl — The Ceiling Reposes

I love the dark blue on grey, the repeated circular form, the choice to obscure part of the photographed image, and the textured grain effect. The thin, cleaner border really makes it.

2. The Japanese House — In The End it Always Does

A similar colour palette to the Lia Kohl (above), and a similar use of subtle whitespace. The imperfection and texture of the hand-drawn arrow has a wonderful wabi-sabi character, and I love everything about the simple type treatment, aligned at the right margin.

1. Boygenius — The Record

I’m tipping my cards a little here, but this is one of those album covers that has the magical property of feeling like the record sounds. In a beautifully simple image, it evokes warmth and friendship, whilst manifesting the music’s sense of reaching for something.

  1. Ranked here purely on consideration of the artwork, though a few of these are records I’ve very much enjoyed. ↩︎

  2. Another album cover I really like. ↩︎

Jun 28, 2023

New member of the family.

Jun 27, 2023

Last night I rewatched David O Russell’s Amsterdam (2022). It’s the director’s loosest-feeling movie since 2004’s I Heart Huckabees, and I really enjoy the pace at which it moves. There is a gentle, consistent ease with which it trips the traps of its plot, and ushers in one guest star after another. Unlike some mystery movies, which feel as though they’re going out of their way to prove the cleverness of their plot, Amsterdam is content simply to let its central knot unwind at a slow, gentle pull. Instead the focus is on the relationships between the central trio: a little cluster of characters imbued — by Bale, Robbie, & Washington — with just the right level of quirk as to remain endearing throughout the 134 minute run time.

Special mention should be made of Emmanuel Lubezki’s cinematography. His work has dazzled me in the past: the gritty urgency of Alfonso Cuarón’s Children of Men (2006), and the captivating ballet of the same director’s Gravity (2013); the breadth of The Revenant (2015), and the bravura “single-take” work on Birdman (2014) both with Alejandro G. Iñárritu. Here, in Amsterdam, he employs a palette of greens, browns, and oranges that give the whole film a lush richness. In the few scenes in which they are missing, their omission is as shocking as any plot twist. 🍿

Jun 26, 2023

Today we ventured out to Whitstable and Herne Bay, to breathe sea air, and walk the coast a little1. We had coffee in Blueprint; walked the cute little back streets; a darting sparrow flew between my legs; we ate fish & chips at a place on the seafront.

I enjoy the difference between the two towns. Whitstable is very much a place where Blueprint — a small batch roastery that is also a tiny bookshop, and stocks a curated collection of Japanese stationery and Blackwing pencils — feels correctly situated. It’s a place of indie bookshops, cute little florists, and artisanal cheesemongers. Herne Bay (only 9km up the road) feels far closer to a traditional English seaside town: greasy spoon cafes, a pier, seagulls making a play for your ice cream cone.

  1. One of the only significant marks against Oxford as a place to live is that it’s 90km from the ocean, as the crow flies. ↩︎

Jun 20, 2023

Back in January, I posted about how I like to pick up a Wallpaper* guide when we’re planning a trip.

Since then, we’ve also bought this fun book from Luster: The 500 Hidden Secrets of Tokyo.

And, this week, a book I’ve been waiting on was finally republished by ORO Editions: Emergent Tokyo: Designing the Spontaneous City.

This one, by architect Jorge Almazán, is less a travel guide and more a deep explanation of how modern Tokyo came to be: its design, infrastructure etc.

Speed Reading Isn't Reading

Jun 20, 2023

I’m a slow reader; always have been. And as someone who loves to read, and who chose to pursue degrees in literature, I’ve long had mixed feelings about the deliberateness with which I’ve found that I need to approach texts1. I reflected on this again recently, as I read a profile of the late Robert Gottlieb:

Gottlieb was a showoff, but not of the athletic sort. When he was in high school, he read “War and Peace” in “a single marathon fourteen-hour session.” As an undergraduate, at Columbia, he read Proust: “seven volumes, seven days.”

Taking the latter of those first, the task of making one’s way through In Search of Lost Time in a week, means reading about 181,000 words per day, for seven days straight. That pace is way beyond my reach, even for a single day! I once read The Catcher in the Rye in one day: it’s 73,404 words, and left little time for anything else.

But it’s turning to the War and Peace claim that really makes me question whether this story about Gottlieb is apocryphal. Tolstoy’s opus is 587,287 words. To read it in a 14 hour sitting as claimed, you’d have to go at a little under 42,000 words per hour, or 700 words per minute, non-stop, for 840 minutes.

It brought to mind that quote, usually attributed to Woody Allen:

I took a speed-reading course and read War and Peace in twenty minutes. It involves Russia.

Whilst searching for that, I found a 1995 letter to the Editor of the NY Times, from communications consultant Dr Phyllis Mindell, in which she decries the practice of ‘speed reading’. Here are a couple of sections that chimed for me:

Study after study demonstrates that although people can skim at extremely high rates (as much as 100,000 words a minute), they gain substantially no comprehension in the process.

This is exactly my experience: fly through the text and I end up with no significant understanding of it. Perhaps because:

[F]ailure must result from any method that assumes that reading is primarily a visual task, that one can “take in whole pages at a single glance,” […] or that the approach to reading remains independent of the content of the material to be read or the purposes of reading

Reading is a practice of comprehension, conducted only at first with the eyes, and then primarily with that miraculous organ directly behind them. The letter quotes a wonderful phrasing of this task, by Stanley Elkin:

The most trenchant critiques of “speed reading” emerge, directly or indirectly, from the strongest readers. The writer Stanley Elkin, for example, called reading “fine, precise, detailed work, the infinitely small motor managements of diamond cutters and safecrackers that we do in our heads."

Just as people who think they’re multi-tasking are more likely doing several things poorly, I remain convinced that ‘speed readers’ are actually just looking at patterns, and not engaged in the act of comprehension that I understand reading to be. 📚

PS It is certainly not my intention here to besmirch the good name of the late Robert Gottlieb, may he rest in peace.

  1. Some things certainly would have been easier if I could have made my way through long novels on syllabi in hours instead of days. ↩︎

Jun 15, 2023

Last night, the book I’ve selected for this year’s summer read-along — Barbara Kingsolver’s Demon Copperhead — was awarded the 2023 Women’s Prize for Fiction. If you’d like to join a group of likeminded folks to read the novel 2 Jul – 13 Aug, you can learn more and sign-up for free here 📚

Jun 13, 2023

I’m really enjoying the first season of Beef on Netflix, and I love the art used for each episode’s title card:

Sipped Ink vol. 9

Jun 11, 2023

In 2014, I started a summer read-along project as a way to (essentially) peer pressure myself into finally completing David Foster Wallace’s giant-sized novel Infinite Jest (1996). I assembled a small group of like-minded readers, and we had a good time reading the book together and sharing our thoughts. Each weekend I sent out an email newsletter, with notes on the week’s reading.

The read-along has now become an annual summer tradition: a growing group of readers take on a lengthy novel together, and I send out a newsletter each Sunday discussing our progress. So far we’ve read eight novels together, and you can browse the archive of those newsletters right here.

The time has now come to start the ball rolling on this summer’s read-along, which I’ll be running between 2 Jul – 13 Aug 2023. When it came to choosing a novel this year, I did a lot of digging around the dark corners of back alley bookshops, browsing the fat, dusty spines of long-forgotten esoteric tomes… and then I chose the novel that won the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction: Barbara Kingsolver’s Demon Copperhead (2022).

This transplanting of Dickens’ David Copperfield (1850) to modern-day Virginia has been called ‘a masterpiece in storytelling’ and ‘a once-in-a-generation novel that breaks and mends your heart in the way only the best fiction can’. Sounds pretty good, right?

If you’d like to learn more about the novel, you could take a look at the publisher’s website. As-and-when you’re excited to sign up for this summer’s read-along, click right here and send the resulting email.

As always, the read-along itself is completely free; the only thing you’ll need is a copy of the book. If you would like to order the paperback, one great option is Bookshop.org — and if you use this link right here I’ll get a little commission, at no extra cost to you!

At 546 pages, it’s the lowest page count for a read-along novel yet, but the good folks at Faber have chosen a font size for the paperback that’s a little on the small side, so I think — in terms of word count — it’s probably similar to Great Circle, or even Murakami’s The Wind-up Bird Chronicle, which we read together in 2015.

I’ll send out an introductory email to subscribers on Sun 2 Jul, and the following weekend an email will arrive on Sun 9 Jul, discussing the first 91 pages of the novel. We’ll be reading at about that pace for six weeks, wrapping up on Sun 13 Aug.

If you have any comments or questions about any of this, just drop me a line. 📚

Apr 18, 2023
Apr 7, 2023
Mar 20, 2023

Since I last posted I’ve read a couple of books, both of them a little disappointing, but by no means without merit:

The first was Gabrielle Zevin’s much-hyped Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow (2022), which I found both frustratingly divorced from the practical realities of the video game industry (in which it is set), and too eager to undermine its female lead by placing her into romantic relationships with virtually every male character in the novel.

The second was Nell Zink’s Avalon (2022), which is dense with ideas, but I found the through-lines of its characters to be too faintly pencilled. It’s not so much that I was clamouring for capital C, capital D: Character Development — but in a novel centred around a young woman moving through various upheavals in life circumstance, I felt something a little lacking. Perhaps I just wanted to close the novel with a more definite sense of Bran having learned something about herself. Equally, perhaps that was not Zink’s project, and she remains an unquestionably fine, endlessly interesting writer.

I also caught a clutch of good movies; let me bullet point them for you:

• The Fabelmans (2022) — catnip for those cinephiles for whom Spielberg has been a constant presence since childhood

• Women Talking (2022) — masterful in every regard

• Men (2022) — Alex Garland’s weirdest, with a truly outré last reel

• Certain Women (2016) — a rewatch of this favourite on International Women’s Day; Kelly Reichardt can do no wrong

• Wheel of Fortune & Fantasy (2021) — almost the equal of Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s other 2021 film: Oscar-winner, Drive My Car

• Empire of Light (2022) — I think I need more room for this one, and may write about it in the newsletter this weekend.

• A Human Position (2022) — I loved the pace of this, and the pride it takes lingering on both Norway’s natural beauty, and its objects of design.

Mar 1, 2023
Feb 25, 2023
Feb 18, 2023

I’m an inveterate highlighter, firmly established in the practice of scribbling down and squirrelling away those phrases and ideas I come across that send a certain type of vibration through me. Recently, I was doing some digital housekeeping and found a trove of older notes, many of which contained snippets I hadn’t thought about in many years, but which shone for me once more upon re-discovering them.

I thought it might be fun — and possibly of value — to share some of these clippings, and since I’m also starting to think about bringing my newsletter out of hibernation1, I figured that might make a good venue. I’ll drop a quote / highlight into future issues, with or without my own commentary as seems appropriate.

As a trial, here’s a framing of the practice of blogging that I like, from this 2011 piece in Huffpost, by Nora Ephron:

One of the most delicious things about the profoundly parasitical world of blogs is that you don’t have to have anything much to say. Or you just have to have a little tiny thing to say. You just might want to say hello. I’m here. And by the way. On the other hand. Nevertheless. Did you see this? Whatever. A blog is sort of like an exhale. What you hope is that whatever you’re saying is true for about as long as you’re saying it. Even if it’s not much.

  1. You can browse the archive, and consider signing up right here ↩︎

Feb 15, 2023

Jockstrap @ The Bullingdon

Feb 14, 2023

Last night I caught a performance by London-based genre-dismantlers Jockstrap at The Bullingdon, on Oxford’s Cowley Rd. It’s a 400-capacity venue that I’ve been to for a few shows, but this was the first time I’ve seen it packed. The band’s current (sold out) tour, in support of debut album I Love You Jennifer B (2022), is also taking them as far afield as Australia & Japan — a further sign that their frenetic, adventurous sound has struck a nerve.

The set list was probably about as balanced as Jockstrap can get, pulling from both the softer side of their oeuvre — songs like the pretty & sad ‘Glasgow’, which Georgia Ellery sings and strums largely solo1 — to the down-right unstable (see eg. ‘Robert’). Most tracks, however, are some mix of styles: the band shifting restlessly between vibes and valences (ie. the danceable middle third of single ‘Concrete Over Water’, a song that is otherwise something approaching a ballad).

One aspect of the sequencing that I really enjoyed, is the way in which following ‘Concrete Over Water’ (2022) with ‘The City’ (2020) makes the earlier track read as a neat coda to the more recent one.

‘Angst’ is a three-minute song on the album that sounds as though it was recorded as a four-minute song, and then had its last quarter compressed into the track’s final ~25 seconds. The effect is similar to that of scrubbing through those final moments of audio, and I would have guessed that it would be achieved live by employing a sample. It was a delight to see Ellery sing it, whilst Taylor Skye pitch-shifted her vocal.

The whole performance was admirably tight, and you could tell the spell was working: the crowd unfailingly remained silent throughout the quieter moments, and exploded into motion on the high-energy songs. Personal favourite ‘Debra’ felt like it landed particularly well.

Finally, what a joy it must be to know you’ve got a bona fide banger like ‘50/50’ in your back pocket to drop as a closer. Even though the (no budget) official video could have been shot at last night’s show, it only goes some way to depicting how much harder the song hits in person.

Re-listening to I Love You Jennifer B ahead of the show (and again this morning) I’m experiencing a little regret that I didn’t find a spot for it on my end of year top 20. It was one of a few records that made a shortlist, but not the final cut. It’s testament to Jockstrap that the live show injects even more vitality to these already super-vibrant songs, and has me second guessing myself.

  1. she is also the violinist in the Mercury Prize-nominated band Black Country, New Road, and brought out the violin a couple of times during the set, to add yet another flavour to the mix ↩︎

My Academic Career in 6 Documents

Feb 6, 2023

Recently, whilst searching shelves for something else entirely, I happened upon the folder of essays I wrote as part of my MA in English & American Literature. Doing so, I was semi-stunned to note that even the most recent of them — the final thesis — is now more than a decade old1. Nevertheless, rather than merely continue sitting in a folder upstairs, I figured it might be time to at least give them a home online2.

You never know who might stumble upon these things after a highly specific search engine query! If that’s you, I hope something here is of interest.

• 2006 Seekers After Truth — The Writings of Chuck Palahniuk
• 2011 Modernism’s Refiguring of Perspective in Literature and the Visual Arts
• 2011 Bodies of Water in Heart of Darkness & In The Skin of a Lion
• 2012 Fragmentation and Palimpsest in Pound’s Pisan Cantos & HD’s Trilogy
• 2012 Multi-authorial Strategies in Pale Fire & House of Leaves
• 2012 Towards a Genealogy of American Literary Minimalism

As always, you can send any comments, criticisms, and questions via email

  1. Heck, it shouldn’t be a surprise; I have a decade-old blogpost about it. ↩︎

  2. I’ve also dug out an older piece: my undergraduate thesis 🫣 ↩︎
