In this respect, whilst little may prevent one from making one’s way through the physical form of a text, the meaning one is able to extract from it will vary depending upon the ‘skill’ of the reader. (This may include vocabulary, imagination, understanding of context, emotional availability, and any number of other factors.) In this respect the text as artwork operates as a partnership between writer & reader: how effectively the former is able to capture in writing the ideas, emotions, and meaning that they desire to convey; and how adroitly the latter is able to decode the same1.

In the case of a game, the responsibilities that lie more or less solely with the author in the above example2 may be distributed across any number of individuals depending on the game: designers who work to construct narrative, atmosphere, mechanics: the world of the game, the way it sounds, its characters, what the player can and cannot affect, and how. By virtue of the inextricable link between player action and progress, the player’s role is shaped by the designer(s). They can certainly choose to move their character in a circle ad infinitum, but no progress will be made. Progress depends upon overcoming the challenges set by the designer(s), and doing so requires skill. Thus, whilst games uniquely gate progress based on player skill, both games and literature require audience attention, effort, and a form of skill in order for their inherent value to be realised.

All of this is just me thinking out loud, and the binary I’ve constructed here is pretty weak. Plenty of writing prioritises enjoyment over meaning, and there are certainly games that seek to provide something to the player other than (or beyond) simple enjoyment. However, I am increasingly convinced that value is an important concept here beyond the simple question of being notionally present for an artwork’s duration.

  1. This is certainly not to say that the value of any artwork is dependant on the clarity with which it communicates the artist’s specific intent. The immense value of personal, individual meaning being derived by the audience is precisely what makes art beautiful and powerful.   ↩︎

  2. Though potential contributions of an editor and/or translator shouldn’t be overlooked.  ↩︎

Mar 12, 2022
Jan 2, 2022

The List 2021

Dec 31, 2021

At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Tyler, The Creator — Call Me If You Get Lost

Tyler hit 12th on my 2019 list with IGOR, an album that captivated and confounded me in equal measure, with its structural inventiveness. That was a poppier affair than we’re in for this time out — Call Me If You Get Lost is more interested in putting a spin on various rap sub-genres. Soul samples and R&B textures ebb & flow throughout another album-as-album exercise in layered production, restless structures, and tongue-in-cheek lifestyle boasting. Once again, Tyler made my favourite hip-hop LP of the year.

19. Weezer — OK Human

Imagine if you were a member of a church, or a friend group or something, and over the years you’d developed a bunch of rites or in jokes or whatever. If you were to try and bring a new person into that circle, they’d meet a wall of resistance in the form of the very shared customs and understanding that you had been enjoying for years. Which is to say: I would not know where to begin if I was tasked with explaining Weezer’s 2021 output to someone who hasn’t been along for the ride with this band for at least two full decades.

Here’s what I will say:

a) OK Human is a sneaky complex album. It was introduced as the lockdown project the band put together in lieu of releasing and touring their love letter to metal: Van Weezer. In truth it’s a pop-rock record with a freaking string section! I don’t think I’ve encountered that since Silverchair tapped Van Dyke Parks as a collaborator in 2002.

b) I wish this record had been released as a freakish Jekyll & Hyde double-album with Van Weezer, so that I could find room for both of them on this list. On balance, this is the more consistently enjoyable of the two LPs, even if it’s something like the band’s sixth best record overall.

c) The best track Weezer released this year (by a country mile) is ‘Sheila Can Do It’, which has been only lightly revised since its 1997 demo version. Take that for what you will.

18. Celeste — Not Your Muse

I was already infatuated with Celeste’s debut by the time it was shortlisted for the 2021 Mercury Prize. Its sonic warmth and thematic vulnerability made for a valued companion throughout year two of the pandemic.

‘Ideal Woman’ is the gentlest beginning, and a perfect showcase for both the richness of Celeste’s voice, and the candidness of her lyrics; ‘Strange’ is an equally tender paean on loss, and then the album begins to open up to a larger sound. What follows is a set of soul and R&B-inflected pop that never falters. The album’s single strongest track is still probably the understated bombast of ‘Love is Back’, but it’s in good company right through to the touching declaration in ‘A Little Love’: “Of all the things to be / I choose a kindness”.

17. Ben Kweller — Circuit Boredom

A round of applause, please, for the first record I listened to this year! Released on 1 January, Kweller’s sixth LP-shaped collection of rock-flavoured, pop-shaped confections as a solo artist has hung on effortlessly for twelve months to make this list. Eight songs and 28 minutes maybe pushes the boundaries of eligibility, but this is as note-perfect a piece of work as BK has released since his eponymous album 15 years ago. It contains all the flavours of Kweller that you know and love: pop stomper (opener ‘Starz’); vulnerable acoustic ballad ((part of) ‘Just For Kids’); & lo-fi crunchy: on album high point ‘Heart Attack Kid’.

If you’re not already a fan, Circuit Boredom isn’t going to change any minds. For the rest of us, however, your face is going to be hurting from smiling by the time you’re singing along to ‘Wanna Go Home’… and then circling right back to play the record again.

16. Ill Considered — Liminal Space

Ill Considered are a hyper-prolific improvisational jazz ensemble. The aptly titled Liminal Space is the group’s first recorded work to mix live performances with post-production elements. Here the central trio of saxophone, bass, and drums are artfully supplemented with additions from guest players, bringing a rich and full-bodied sound to initially improvised pieces.

This is complex and high-paced music, with some tracks (eg. ‘The Lurch’ and ‘Light Trailed’) featuring time signatures so complicated they can overwhelm. However, listening via headphones, and surrendering to the build and swell, I found few listening experiences more rewarding this year.

(Side note: the album features one of the year’s best covers, by Dutch artist Vincent de Boer.)

15. Koreless — Agor

‘Yonder’ is an expanding bloom of a curtain raiser before the real action begins, and then it’s off to the races for a half hour of dense electronica that plays masterfully with tension and release. There’s a wide instrumental palate at play throughout, such as on ‘White Picket Fence’: built out of eerie synths, fuzzy bass keys, and a somersaulting set of vocal samples played as an instrument. Likewise ‘Joy Squad’ makes use of dehumanised vocal stabs set amid a bed of alarming cinematic strings and skittering beats.

Tracks often increase in intensity and complexity, pushing on when they feel almost like they should back off – but beyond these thresholds, Koreless often finds a place of euphoric calm.

14. Bicep — Isles

The second LP from Northern Irish electronica twosome Bicep is an exercise in treading the line between headphones and the dance floor. For me it became a go-to AirPods-in record — its grooves (some trance, some more propulsive) lushly mixed and captivating throughout a varied tracklist. Drawing on a deep pool of samples, from Hindi bops to Turkish pop, Bicep weave a rich and ever-shifting sonic tapestry. Album highlight ‘Apricots’ pulls together Bulgarian folk with a Malawian polyrhythmic vocal to astounding effect.

13. Japanese Breakfast — Jubilee

Here’s a band that I feel bad about having paid too little attention to previously. Two albums (Psychopop (2016) & Soft Sounds From Another Planet (2017)) have passed without me noticing, and it took — of all things — an exceptionally good video game soundtrack (for this autumn’s low key, exploration-focussed coming-of-age game Sable) to really put Japanese Breakfast on my radar.

I was only a couple of tracks into my first listen of Jubilee before I was almost literally kicking myself. Here was the soft-focussed, pastel-hued update to Bat For Lashes' sound that I hadn’t realised I wanted. Ambitious, expansive pop music that is unafraid to experiment with weirder tonal inclusions.

My former neglectfulness now corrected, band leader Michelle Zauner’s memoir is even on my Kindle ready for holiday reading, and I will certainly be awaiting whatever comes next musically.

12. Moin — Moot!

Here’s an unexpected pleasure from the summer. Moot! is a strangely out-of-time artefact deeply reverent of 90s post-hardcore. Intense no matter which of its numerous gears it’s operating in, it’s the closest thing to Fugazi or Slint that I’ve encountered in quite a while. ‘Right is Alright, Wrong is to Belong’ is a haunting claustrophobic crawl, whereas ‘Lungs’ is more animated, with wilder swings. Much of the album retains an almost live-seeming feel, owing to the record’s few-frills production, which only adds to its Sub Pop-adjacent charms.

Overall, it was an absolute pleasure to surrender time and again to the waves of distorted guitar, the inventive bass lines, and Valentina Magaletti’s frenetic percussion.

11. Ross From Friends — Tread

Felix Weatherall’s trick to making his second record for Brainfeeder was to write an additional piece of bespoke software that sat on his laptop and just began recording automatically when his compositions met certain parameters. This method, implemented to overcome procrastination and choice paralysis, has resulted in a diverse set of electronica that hangs together remarkably well despite the swings from track-to-track. ‘Revellers’ starts from a pure house foundation and builds something deep and sprawling; ‘Morning Sun in a Dusty Room’ is a three-minute slice of glowing ambience; and ‘Life in a Mind’ takes a soul sample for a kinetic trip punctuated by a brief, affecting melancholy dip.

10. Vijay Iyer, Linda May Han Oh, & Tyshawn Sorey — Uneasy

Earlier in the year I found myself returning repeatedly to the same video of Snarky Puppy performing their 10 minute opus ‘Lingus’ to a stunned studio audience. And, whilst Cory Henry’s keyboard solo is undoubtedly the showpiece, I became fascinated by the drumming of Larnell Lewis. This sent me on a bit of a jazz drumming journey in the middle part of the year, and I found Uneasy at exactly the right time to get hypnotised by Tyshawn Sorey’s intricate, constantly surprising work.

Alongside Sorey here are longtime collaborator Linda May Han Oh on bass, and Iyer at the piano. Each is an extraordinary player, and the combination feels natural and marvellous. This may be their first record together, but I certainly hope it’s not the last. The trio has fast become one of my very favourite configurations for jazz, precisely because of the way it allows for both interplay and the spotlighting of individual excellence. A few of the tracks here have been reworked from compositions originally for sextets or even string orchestras, and the increased intimacy is something I really valued: the opportunity to spend time with each of the exceptional players within the frameworks of these spacious arrangements.

9. St. Vincent — Daddy’s Home

An artist as restlessly inventive as Annie Clark was never likely to settle for making more of the same. So, Daddy’s Home heralds a new look, a new persona, and a new sound. A very definite 90-degree turn from Masseduction (6th in 2017), here 70s synth tones colour the album’s experiments with soul, blues, and even hints at psychedelia (‘Live in the Dream’). But, as always, Clark’s treading her own path through these pastures. ‘The Melting of the Sun’ manages to be both melancholy and unsettling, interweaved with a stirring soul background vocal. ‘Down’ borrows the vocal progression from Nirvana’s ‘You Know You’re Right’, and transplants it into a funk-rock setting. And ‘My Baby Wants a Baby’ is a brilliant, cutting, tongue-in-cheek update to Sheena Easton’s Prozac-happy 1980 anthem to obedient housewifery: ‘Morning Train (Nine to Five)’.

Clark remains consistently one of the artists I’m most fascinated by. I haven’t yet got around to the recently-released documentary / horror movie (?) The Nowhere Inn, but I’ve every faith it’s a continuation of her ceaseless playing with persona and form. I will happily follow wherever she chooses to go next.

Side note: this record also brings producer Jack Antonoff back to my list for the forth year out of the last five. Varied as the sounds have been across his projects with St Vincent and Taylor Swift, he’s reaching the status of producer whose name alone will make me try a record.

8. Halsey — If I Can’t Have Love, I Want Power

When Halsey hit second spot on my list last year, it was with an emo / pop-rock album peppered with outside influences: folk, R&B, Korean rap…. It was a curious mix that worked supremely well on me, but certainly left me perplexed as to what a follow-up would sound like. I would not have predicted the menacing, polygenre tour-de-force that this collaboration with Trent Reznor & Atticus Ross has yielded.

At heart Halsey has described the record as a concept album about the beauty and horror of pregnancy and birth. Many of their lyrics have a destructive bent, even when fascinated by acts of love and creation. Tender vocals over a sea of dark synths; a mélange of hopes and fears. It’s a tension that makes for a record constantly wrestling with itself, content only to keep moving forward and growing as it goes.

‘Easier Than Lying’ would be at home on a Grimes record, and ‘Girl is a Gun’ (with its hyperkinetic breakbeat) could be a lost Robyn classic. Over here we have Lindsay Buckingham fingerpicking guitar on the simple, beautiful ‘Darling’. Two tracks later, here’s Dave Grohl providing drums for the bittersweet straight-ahead rock of ‘Honey’. More than three months since the album’s release, I’m still trying to figure out how it works as well as it does. Like Manic the recipe and the dynamics at play are a mystery, but the results are inarguable.

7. Madlib — Sound Ancestors

When MF DOOM passed toward the end of 2020, I found myself returning to one record in particular: 2004’s Madvillainy colab between the late rapper and producer Madlib. In turn I had originally come to that record primarily via a 2005 EP of remixes by Four Tet. So, it felt like a circle completing itself in some way, to tune into Sound Ancestors. Here Kieran Hebden is on editing & arranging duties, and the result is a constantly shifting soundscape of beats and interweaving vocal samples.

I don’t listen to nearly enough instrumental hip-hop, with my most prominent touchstone being J Dilla’s 2006 LP Donuts – a record I considered during last year’s effort to figure out my all time favourite albums. There’s a nod to Dilla here (on ‘Two For 2’), and the highest compliment I can pay Sound Ancestors is that it’s operating in the same rarefied air as that masterpiece.

6. Jade Bird — Different Kinds of Light

I had been so impatient for a follow-up to Jade Bird’s debut (2nd place on my list in 2019) that the universe decided to play a trick on me. Like many artists, her entire tour was postponed multiple times throughout the pandemic, including the shows to which I had tickets. My disappointment at missing my opportunity to see how she does it live was alleviated, however, when she scheduled a series of intimate album launch shows – one of them a literal three minute walk from my front door. That show, which was simply Bird solo with an acoustic guitar, proved beyond any doubt that she is the genuine article.

The self-titled debut album was so good that I had all but convinced myself it was impossible to follow up. In that respect, Different Kinds of Light proved me entirely wrong in the best way possible. Not only are there multiple songs here every bit as captivating as the cream of the first record, there’s also an admirable sense of Bird expanding her sound – exploring further some of the avenues of country and Americana that the first record hinted at. Best song on the record? Pick anything beginning with an ‘H’ and I won’t argue.

5. Low — Hey What

Back when I gave Low 6th place on my 2018 list, for Double Negative, I remarked upon my ignorance of the band’s substantial back catalogue, and suggested that it was an error I should fix. Well, I am ashamed to admit that I have not done that work. Instead, I waited until Hey What came out this September, to experience all over again the shocking power of their brand of colossal-sounding, meditatively paced rock.

For this recording at least, the band is now down to a duo (bassist Steve Garrington having departed last year). The interplay between Mimi Parker & Alan Sparhawk (who are also married) is the band’s defining strength however, particularly their exceptional vocal harmonies, which retain the power to soothe and stir even when under several layers of detuned, distorted cacophony.

Maybe a second truly exceptional album in a row will finally push me to go back and explore three decades of output. There’s every chance Low could turn out to be one of my favourite bands.

4. Bachelor — Doomin' Sun

Jay Som took top spot on my 2017 list for the exemplary lo-fi bedroom pop album Everybody Works; and Palehound I (shamefully) have no prior familiarity with. As such, I didn’t know exactly what to expect when coming to their collaboration: Bachelor. What I found was a half hour of subtle but raw interrogations of the complex textures of love between women. The sonic palate is less synth and a little more guitar-centric than Jay Som’s solo work, but it’s still operating in largely the same spaces as I found so magnetic from Everybody Works & Turn Into (2016).

Above all, this project appears brimming with the energy of two likeminded musical souls, effortlessly complementing one another in telling shared stories. ‘Back of My Hand’ is a declaration of admiration, powerful despite its relaxed flow. ‘Sick of Spiralling’ is, in some respects, that song’s flipside: fuelled by fear as well as love. To my mind though, the album’s high point is the Pixies-meets-That Dog blur and buzz of ‘Stay in the Car’.

3. Priya Ragu — damnshestamil

Thought and prayers to anyone who has to decide how to file this record by category. Opener ‘Leaf High’ — as well as being an introduction to Ragu’s soaring, honeyed voice — is an exemplary piece of low key soul with a hip-hop inflection. It also contains a lyric referencing “paper planes”, which I couldn’t help but read as a sly nod to Maya Arulpragasam — aka MIA — with whom Ragu has in common both Tamil heritage and musical eclecticism.

Three minute pop gem ‘Good Love 2.0’ has song-of-the-summer energy, and ‘Lockdown’ is an infectious mix of R&B and hip-hop across a South Asian-inflected beat. It shifts between adamant and euphoric with ease, an admirable trick that is also at work on one of the record’s several highlights: ‘Chicken Lemon Rice’.

‘Forgot About’ is a straight-ahead R&B ballad of exceptional quality. Here, as elsewhere, some of Ragu’s choices of vocal inflections remind me of no one more strongly than Janet Jackson – a comparison I do not make lightly. I am excited to see where she goes after a debut like this.

2. Turnstile — Glow On

The number of guitar bands that excite me has certainly waned over the last decade or so, but alongside Biffy Clyro and a resurgent Deftones, Turnstile prove here that there’s still plenty of life in the scene if you know where to find it. I certainly did not expect to be making two comparisons to Fugazi when writing this year’s list, but just like with Moin, it’s the Washington legends' influence that I hear as coal to Turnstile’s roaring fire.

Turnstile’s update to hardcore, however, is inflected with synth atmospherics and an armload of borrowings from other genres. It actively rejects hardcore’s (often misguided) reputation for self-seriousness, partly by unashamedly embracing anthemics, whilst retaining the source material’s commitment to volume and enthusiasm. Glow On is an exercise in loud, direct sincerity distilled into concentrated sub-three minute bursts of whatever-works rock.

PS. hearing guest Dev Hynes in a hardcore setting sent me back to Test Icicles' For Screening Purposes (14th on my list in 2005), and it’s still a lot of fun.

1. Olivia Rodrigo — SOUR

Olivia has experienced a break-up, and her former boyfriend is now with someone else. This very specific scenario is the impetus behind at least seven songs on SOUR, making it a kind of concept album about a heartbreak tinged with feelings of anger and inadequacy.

Some of the guest writing credits give a hint of the sonic palate. Hayley Williams helps inject some Paramore power-pop into ‘Good 4 U’, and Taylor Swift’s recent sensibilities are evident on ‘1 Step Forward, 3 Steps Back’: a fragile piano ballad of surpassing beauty. Then there’s ‘Deja Vu’, as powerfully self-assured as it is potently infused with bitterness — tellingly it was written by the superhero team-up of Rodrigo, Swift, and Annie Clark.

Honestly though, there is not a weak song here, and there are several that are truly world class; perhaps the best of all is the achingly vulnerable, yet steel-spined, ‘Traitor’. Unimpeachable song of the year material.

Ultimately, nothing can compete when a three minute pop gem goes off in my chest like a cherry bomb, and this year Olivia Rodrigo came armed to the teeth.

⏎ Return to the index of lists

Dec 5, 2021

Nathan Harris — The Sweetness of Water (2021)

Oct 31, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

I came to Nathan Harris’s novel as the last of the thirteen titles longlisted for the 2021 Booker Prize, and after it had dropped out of contention (its absence from the shortlist having been announced in September). I was delighted to find a novel at once enormously readable and admirably in tune with human feeling, which depicted a period too little investigated: the days immediately following the post-American Civil War emancipation of enslaved people.

In an interview with Oprah Winfrey, Harris says that part of his ambition with The Sweetness of Water was to tell a new facet of the history of enslavement and emancipation. Specifically, he wished to provide an experience for the reader akin to his own when first reading Edward P Jones’s novel The Known World (2003). Jones’s novel deals, in part, with the matter of Black people who owned slaves; it was something Harris had not previously considered, and a revelation that cast new light on a period of American history too often calcified into the dry repetition of fact.

Harris sets about his task by interweaving two little-told stories. The first, the lives of formerly-enslaved brothers Landry & Prentiss; the second, a homosexual relationship between two civil war soldiers1. Enriching these two narratives is a cast of vibrantly drawn characters, and a setting — the fictional town of Old Ox — as distinct and well-realised as any I’ve encountered in a novel for some time. All of which richness Harris employs to great effect in a novel endlessly generous in the gifts of its plot. The Sweetness of Water is replete with captivating action, compellingly told. This begins fairly early, when Harris develops the characters of George & Isabelle, and then switches to their son’s point of view so as to offer the reader new insight. The plot, which builds gradually through an opening section more engaged in establishing the world of Old Ox, only gathers pace throughout – its author keeping a lot of irons in the fire. No sooner is the true nature of Caleb & August’s relationship revealed to the reader, than Landry is murdered. Soon thereafter Prentiss is arrested, and then we switch to Isabelle confronting Clementine about George’s supposed infidelity. These are but some of the beats of the novel’s second act.

A cynical reader may be inclined to charge the novel with a reliance upon familiar character tropes and incident. Yes, this is a story featuring a corrupt sheriff, a pure-hearted prostitute, and hateful former enslavers. Rivers are forded and shots are fired. There is even an epic wildfire that plays at once like tragedy and allegory2. It is to Harris’s enormous credit that he uses these ingredients to tell an uncommon story, and one rich with human feeling. Likewise, in the previously mentioned interview, Harris acknowledges that he may be open to the accusation of having employed the trope of a white saviour. Part of his project, in The Sweetness of Water however, is to show the immediate effects of emancipation upon all manner of people: those freed, those who formerly enslaved them, and also those who would seek to help the formerly enslaved begin new lives. The novel is interested in the consequences for people like George, Isabelle, and Caleb, just as it is in the fates of Landry and Prentiss.

Harris is a gifted writer at the level of the sentence. Consider the poetry, and the talent for empathic insight, at work in this passage from the novel’s third chapter, depicting the moment in which the brothers are granted their freedom:

The notion of true emancipation had always seemed so fantastical that, were it to occur, Prentiss had expected the heralds of a bugle, rows of men in lockstep who would descend upon Majesty’s Palace like angels brought down to serve the aims of God himself. In the actual event it was nothing but a few young men in blue uniforms as scraggy as the clothes that Prentiss and Landry had on themselves.

Importantly, the author is also a skilful conductor of theme. In the same early chapter he introduces the concept of freedom as a distant place:

And it grew clear that the only path to a life worth living would be found elsewhere, where they might not have more but could not possibly have less.

He then carries this idea throughout the novel, in moments such as this from two-thirds of the way through the text:

Prentiss retreated into himself. He knew how to live in his head. He’d made a similar journey every day in the fields, wandering in his mind’s eye to a place he’d never been, a place that was equal parts destination and idea. Elsewhere was the only name it carried. The barn beside George’s cabin was elsewhere; a patch of free ground up north was elsewhere; his mother was elsewhere; salvation was elsewhere; all those lives that passed outside the jail existed elsewhere (praise be to their good fortune); and a fate, any fate, other than the one that lay before him would be a perfectly fine road to elsewhere. The map, with all its many variations, was in his head, yet he knew quite well he would never make the journey.

In this way Harris builds towards Prentiss (& Caleb) eventually fleeing the farm, in the hope of escaping their lot and finding better lives. I found it particularly inspired that once this occurs, we are given relatively little of what lies beyond the horizon for the pair; instead Harris lingers upon those who remain. Isabelle’s attempts to build something worthy of those whom she has lost (George and Landry, but also Caleb and Prentiss) is touching without undue sentimentality. Likewise, I felt palpably Prentiss’s longing for his absent mother. The novel is grounded enough not to reunite them, and yet it ends on a note of hope, as resilient as the new life conjured from Isabelle’s razed farm.

Having come to The Sweetness of Water as the final novel in my 2021 Booker Prize marathon (the sequencing almost entirely random, I should note), I’m saddened not to see it on the shortlist. It is every bit as vastly entertaining as Maggie Shipstead’s Great Circle, and more coherently thoughtful in conception of its world than Richard Powers’s comparatively laboured Bewilderment. No special consideration should be owed to debut novels, of course, but Harris’s is a remarkably impressive achievement – whatever follows will certainly be worthy of close attention.

  1. It is worth noting that the novel spends less time on the latter of these stories, though it informs Caleb’s character throughout. ↩︎

  2. Though not a direct comparison perhaps, I was reminded somewhat of the power of Jane Smiley’s superb 1991 novel A Thousand Acres. ↩︎

Damon Galgut — The Promise (2021)

Oct 24, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The Promise is an ambitious novel, encompassing the stories of the lives (and deaths) of two generations of the Swart family. Its spine transcribes the long arc between the making, and the keeping, of the titular promise: that a particular property on the family’s land be given to their maid. It is a novel rich with insight into South African history, and which makes exemplary use of an intriguing cast of central characters to paint a wider picture of injustice, fallibility, and unfulfilled ambition.

The central story of the novel is captivating enough, but the book’s standout aspect is the manner in which it is narrated. Galgut has chosen to write from a perspective not constrained to multiple first-persons, or even free indirect third-person, but which also stops somewhere short of omniscience. Early in the novel the narrator mistakenly uses the word ‘hearse’ before correcting itself to ‘house’. Not long after comes the first of several direct references to the reader, telling us that one of the novel’s characters ‘dislikes her whole body, as many of you do’. It is narration with personality, as interested in seemingly minor detail as it is in the lives of the central characters. As the novel progresses, it is never less than impressive to see how Galgut affects transitions between perspective with minimal friction. In an interview with Europa Editions, Galgut says that this form of narrative perspective shifting was partly inspired by work he had been doing on a screenplay. The process, he says, taught him that ‘a narrator could act like a camera’. As adapted to the page, however, it also takes on an aspect of interiority which evades the cinematic lens. We are given a rich depiction of an interior funeral scene, before we skip for a beat into the perspective of the family’s dog. During a city scene, the novel takes a diversion from its central cast to inhabit the unusual vantage of a (possibly mentally ill) homeless man.

I will admit that my initial impression of this technique was to become overly preoccupied with the identity of the narrator. As I settled into the text, however, I came to recognise that Galgut was employing a variation on narrative techniques familiar from the height of the modernist novel. The blurring and leaking of perspective allows the novel to breach barriers, pushing beyond what its characters know, and also beyond the constraints of the immediate narrative. In the aforementioned interview, Galgut speaks of the way in which he feels that South African literature is freighted with the expectation: ‘no matter how small your story it has to carry the weight of the country’s history’. In this there is an echo of JM Coetzee’s comment that the country’s letters represent a ‘literature in bondage’. We might read Galgut’s shaping of narrative perspective as an attempt to wrestle with that burden, and to free itself — in some respect — from those shackles. In his review for The Guardian, Jon Day found that it fell short in some respects:

If the results are mixed, this might be because the novel sometimes strives too hard to present a balanced collective perspective, or because it fails to reconcile aesthetic with moral questions.

For the most part, I found the manner in which the novel is written to be enormously effective, and I felt this lack of neat reconciliation to represent a deliberate admission of difficulty and complexity. By offering us a ceaseless chorus of contributing perspectives, Galgut succeeds in conveying the fact that the context is far larger than any one story can encompass. As James Wood puts it in his review of the novel for The New Yorker:

Though Galgut’s narrator has the authority of omniscience, it’s used lightly, glancingly, so that this perilous all-knowingness often makes his characters not more transparent but more mysterious.

There were individual moments when I felt that the novel’s voice attempted something overly cute, or too arch. One example comes at the novel’s culmination, when the narrator takes aim at Galgut’s ending, calling the use of pathetic fallacy a ‘cheap, redemptive symbol’. These instances when I acutely felt the wink at the reader were, however, very few in comparison to the times when I was deeply impressed by Galgut’s command of perspective and tone.

By virtue of the context in which I read The Promise, I am drawn to make comparison with another title shortlisted for the 2021 Booker Prize: Anuk Arudpragasam’s A Passage North1. Like Galgut, Arudpragasam skilfully utilises his protagonist as a starting point to examine a country’s evolving political circumstances (in this case Sri Lanka), and the manner in which they impact individual lives. A Passage North is a quieter novel, more content to linger upon certain of its questions. By comparison, Galgut (or, at least his narrator) often seems eager to move on to the next perspective, digression, or time period. To my mind, it makes for an interesting contrast in technique, and does nothing to disparage either work.

  1. You can find my notes on that novel, here ↩︎

Richard Powers — Bewilderment (2021)

Oct 17, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The thirteenth novel by Richard Powers – his first since the Booker-shortlisted, and Pulitzer-winning The Overstory (2018) – is a meditation on climate disaster, personal responsibility, and empathy. It is a novel that plays out at various scales, from a relationship between father and son, to the arena of national policymaking, to the circumstances of imagined life on theoretical planets. Powers is certainly a gifted writer, and he is possessed of both a vast imagination and an impressively thorough command of facts. However, I found that several elements of the novel frustrated me, from the way its characters are drawn, to the tone and manner in which its overall narrative is composed.

With the caveat that this may all be subjective to my own experience, I’ll begin with the textual, stylistic elements of Bewilderment that irked me. The most common was the myriad ways in which Powers awkwardly introduces facts about the natural world (or the universe more broadly) into the text, through Theo’s narration. In contrast to his relatable concern for his son, and his grieving for his late wife, these interjections repeatedly struck me as off key. Not only did it feel unlikely that anyone genuinely thinks in these hyper-specific bursts of rational fact, it began to feel like the work of the text to convey information rather than story or feeling. It read as though Powers, in his research, had uncovered dozens of things he found so fascinating that he couldn’t stand to leave them out of the text. The result was that I sometimes found Theo’s narration unrealistic and disappointingly flat. Take, as one example, the way in which he relays a simple taxi journey:

I felt us traveling on a small craft, piloting through the capital city of the reigning global superpower on the coast of the third largest continent of a smallish, rocky world near the inner rim of the habitable zone of a G-type dwarf star that lay a quarter of the way out to the edge of a dense, large, barred, spiral galaxy that drifted through a thinly spread local cluster in the dead center of the entire universe. (p210)

It reads like a particularly erudite teenager trying too hard to impress: to overwhelm with fact. In Powers’ case it is more likely an effort to reveal to the reader some of his narrator’s interior, but I found it no more convincing (and no less irritating) each time something like it occurred.

I had a similar experience with the character of Robin. Particularly in the second act of the novel — as he is changed by his treatment away from a recognisably petulant nine year old, into someone preternaturally empathetic and knowledgeable — he began to function in the text similarly to Leonard Stecyk in David Foster Wallace’s The Pale King (2011): a character whose flawless, self-possessed goodness is matched only by how irritating everyone else finds him. Unlike in Wallace’s novel, however, this is almost certainly not how Powers wants his reader to feel about Robin.

Similarly, I found the rendering of Aly to be cartoonishly simple. She is written as an unimpeachable font of altruism and empathy, devoid of human flaws. Her absence, which is required by the plot, nevertheless read to me as a device by which to sustain her sainthood. In the world of the novel, and specifically in the eyes of Theo and Robin, nothing short of Aly’s martyrdom will suffice. It is the impossible, impractical standard against which everyone else in the text is found wanting.

All of which brings me to the broader issues I had with Bewilderment: the ways in which it is confused by its telescoping sense of scale, and – most strikingly – its pervasive sense of pessimism.

The ambitious manner in which the novel moves back and forth between the scales of the family and the intergalactic is admirable, but it also works to the novel’s detriment in one important regard. By counterpointing Aly’s obsession with practical solutions to present problems, and Theo’s focus on theoretical explorations of unreachably distant worlds, the novel becomes confused about its stakes. What does it matter whether or not Theo can help his son, if Earth will be uninhabitable by the time Robin is a man? And what does Earth’s accelerating climate disaster really matter in the grander scale of the observable universe? These are fascinating questions, which I found Bewilderment willing to ask, but unwilling to venture answers to. I came away frustrated by the manner in which Bewilderment raises problems at all scales, without offering hope that they might be effectively addressed.

In fact, the novel’s repeated hammering on humanity’s failings, and the consequences thereof, becomes increasingly depressing. Bewilderment is shot through with pessimism not just in the beat-to-beat litany of personal, familial, and bureaucratic shortcomings, but also in the shape of its plot as a whole. There is certainly something captivating and bittersweet in much of Robin’s arc. His rising out of the prison of his own volatile emotions into beatific empathy, only to decline once more when his treatment becomes unavailable, reminded me of Oliver Sacks’s Awakenings (1973)1. However, Powers chooses to end Bewilderment with Robin’s death. It is presented, alongside the cancellation of the NextGen project and therefore the scuppering of Theo’s life’s work, as a one-two punch that leaves the reader in no doubt as to the message Powers is sending – a pessimism of empathy, politics, and purpose that felt depressing to read.

In a 2018 review for The Atlantic, Nathaniel Rich noted the dour outlook of Powers’ previous novel, The Overstory:

“Humankind is deeply ill, […] The species won’t last long.” This is the consensus among Powers’s characters, and it’s a darkly optimistic one. Optimistic for the planet, pessimistic for the fate of humanity. Once man clears out, nature will return.

The same assessment could be made of Bewilderment. Whilst it is to be lauded for its willingness to look directly at the most difficult and colossal of problems, the novel is too analytical, and too trenchantly rational in its perspective, to inspire. It lacks poetry, most notably through its narrative voice, but also more widely in the construction of its narrative.

In one throwaway moment a fellow ‘planet-hunter’ remarks to Theo that he is lucky to have a son like Robin: “I can’t understand why my boys love Star Wars more than they love the stars.” (p219) One possible answer is that Star Wars —like a lot of fantasy, and like much of the sci-fi Theo professes to enjoy — is a story of hope. Such stories have captivated the human imagination, and served as sources of inspiration, for centuries. As well composed as it is, I can’t imagine Bewilderment inspiring much besides apathy or despair.

  1. Or, more specifically, Penny Marshall’s 1990 film adaptation thereof. ↩︎

Oct 13, 2021
Oct 12, 2021

Nadifa Mohamed — The Fortune Men (2021)

Oct 10, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

It is a more difficult thing in many respects, for the writer to base events and characters in a novel upon real people and real occurrences. When inventing from whole cloth, there is no burden upon the author to maintain accuracy, or to do justice to those who once lived. Indeed, the people and events depicted in Nadifa Mohamed’s The Fortune Men are yet within living memory, still further freighting her novel with responsibilities not incumbent upon those novels wholly invented.

Fortunately (no pun intended), Mohamed is a gifted writer and a subtle stylist. She is engaged — in The Fortune Men — with telling the story of Mahmood Mattan: a Somali man who lived in Cardiff, where he was wrongfully accused of, and eventually hanged for, the murder of a local shopkeeper in 1952. In a piece for Waterstones, Mohamed says that with her novel she ‘tried to touch hands with who Mahmood might really have been’. She does so by employing an admirable gift for empathy, bringing forth a wholly realised sense of many of the novel’s characters with nuanced phrasing. Mahmood, as vital and solid a presence as he is in the text, exists in Cardiff as ‘a human silhouette in motion’, marginalised because of his nationality, race, and class. In a novel very much concerned with one’s sense of place and belonging, Mahmood’s romantic relationship ‘has fixed him in his longitude and latitude’. And Mohamed is just as gifted at depicting place through powerfully evocative use of simile and metaphor. She writes of the river that ‘brooded beneath the bridges, black and muscular’, and door locks that go ‘click, clack […] like small bones breaking’.

Indeed, the weakest aspect of The Fortune Men is the extended section of directly reported speech that makes up Mahmood’s trial. This stylistic choice certainly does something to convey feelings of helplessness and unfairness that characterise the proceedings. However, I was left feeling that I was being deprived of Mahmood’s significant talents for description and interiority, on display throughout the majority of the novel.

Taken as a whole, The Fortune Men is a beautifully written fictionalisation of a tragedy, thick with unresolved questions about national identities, and ideas of belonging. Beyond even that, it is a deceptively ambitious novel, which expands to include the Jewish ancestry of the murder victim’s family, beginning to interrogate the diversity and commonalities of the immigrant experience. By bringing forth a vivid depiction of an all-too-recent miscarriage of justice, Mohamed — the first British-Somali to find a place on the Booker Prize shortlist — also attempts to grapple with the myriad ways in which identity can still shape circumstance in modern Britain. Interviewed in The Guardian recently, she framed it in terms of her own desire for understanding:

Modern-day Britain is intense. Something strange is happening [and] whatever postcolonial psychosis it is is so mad and so extreme. Being black, being Muslim, being someone who up until quite recently thought that they understood this country, I’m desperate to understand what’s going on.

Francis Spufford — Light Perpetual (2021)

Oct 3, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The opening section of Francis Spufford’s excellent novel Light Perpetual brings to mind the experimental fiction of Nicholson Baker, and specifically Mezzanine (1988), a book that unfolds entirely within the duration of an escalator ride. Here, Spufford distills a moment down into its constituent parts, slicing them ever thinner as though in an effort to prevent the V2 rocket that is destined to destroy the New Cross Road branch of Woolworths, from ever landing. Ultimately, however, the tragic fact of history will not be denied.

This instant – this interval of time, measurably tiny, immeasurably vast – arrives unwitnessed, passes unwitnessed, ends unwitnessed. (p5)

This impressive piece of writing provides a somewhat misleading opening to what thereafter unfolds as a novel in a fairly standard realist mode. It is, however, a necessary one, giving a frame to Spufford’s project of bringing forth from real rubble a set of invented lives, and through them providing expertly-rendered tableaus of 20th century London1.

In an interview for the Hay Festival, Spufford references Michael Apted’s Up series of documentaries as one point of reference for his model. In those films, as in Light Perpetual, the audience is granted a series of windows into the lives of several individuals, at intervals – intervening years illuminated only by the glow of the glimpsed present. This technique of temporally constraining the narrative can’t help but call to mind totemic works such as Woolf’s The Waves (1931), and Joyce’s Ulysses (1922). Free from such unfair comparisons however, Spufford’s novel deserves praise for its many strengths.

I found some of the most impressive sections to be those chronicling Ben’s struggles with acute, pervasive anxiety. It’s an unsettling portrait of compulsion and fear, and a bravura piece of writing. Indeed, Spufford shows no signs of faltering with any of the novel’s narratives: Alec’s comparatively less fraught journey from print worker to head teacher is rich throughout with considered observations and human feeling2. At the sentence level too, Spufford is consistently strong, and sometimes spectacular. Consider the concision and richness of this introduction for a minor character:

Trevor is six foot three and won a heavyweight title while he was in the merchant navy. He is also a deacon in the Joyful Assemblies of the Holy Spirit: but he doesn’t feel he is under an obligation to spell out his commitment to the path of heavenly peace in situations where the greater good would be served by keeping shtum. (p102)

Or this meditation, one of many that touch upon the novel’s central theme of what might have been for any one of us:

Then just as suddenly, just as clear, she thinks: so what. Nobody chooses who they love. Possessing something, being somebody, loving anyone, it rules the rest out, and so it’s quieter than being young, and looking forward, and expecting it all, that’s all. The world calms down when your choice is made. (p297)

My only real criticism of the writing was the occasional use of a technique that is one of my literary bugbears: the describing of (particularly non-white) skin colour by way of comparison to foods. It is always irksome, but sits particularly awkwardly here, in a novel that features a character suffering with a pronounced phobia of cannibalism.

On the whole, Light Perpetual is tender without being sentimental. It is interested in both the overarching shape of a life and the seemingly banal minutiae that comprise it. Spufford refrains from providing easy solutions to the real, complex issues with which his characters are faced3. He does not rescue them from their collective premature demise in order to grant them easy, uncomplicated lives. His aim is to explore the myriad paths that may have lay ahead, and which were so brutally truncated. In doing so he expertly weaves some parallel threads through the lives of several of his characters, without ever making it feel showy or heavy-handed. There is, for example, the repeated presence of music: the gospel that Ben is moved by in church; Jo’s career as both performer and teacher; Vern’s refuge in opera. As the characters’ lives lengthen, the reader begins to tease out these universalities in a satisfying way that also enforces the novel’s purpose.

The novel ends with Francis Spufford achieving a delicate balance between evoking the colossal, unknowable, randomness of life to which every person is subject, and simultaneously finding a way to express unequivocally that each one of those lives is unique and important. It’s a very fine piece of writing at every level, and one to which I will return.4

  1. I should mention that, particularly before it expanded its horizons somewhat (sending Jo to LA, and Vern to Glyndebourne), another of the works that Light Perpetual brought to mind for me, was an experimental, illustrated book by Iain Sinclair & Dave McKean, titled Slow Chocolate Autopsy: Incidents from the Notorious Career of Norton, Prisoner of London (1997). I don’t know if that book is still in print, but it made an impression on my as a teenager. ↩︎

  2. I simply have to mention that there is a wonderful short documentary available to watch online for free covering the New York Times’s switch from hot-metal type to computerised setting: Farewell – ETAOIN SHRDLU – 1978 (1980). ↩︎

  3. One possible exception is the deus ex embolism that frees one character from a nasty vice. ↩︎

  4. For what it’s worth, I also think it’s a near-certainty for the Booker Prize shortlist, and a strong contender for the prize. ↩︎

Pembrokeshire

Sep 29, 2021

Last week we spent a few days on the Welsh coast, at a place named Moylegrove — a little south of Cardigan. We were staying in a birch shepherd’s hut, part way down one of the narrowest, twistiest roads I’ve ever encountered, in an area where GPS, data services, and phone signal of any kind feared to tread.

We managed to fit quite a bit into the days, visiting Cardigan, Tenby, Fishguard, an Iron Age settlement, and a five-millennia old burial mound of standing stones. We also spent time walking the Stackpole Loop (Stackpole Quay → Barafundle Bay → Stackpole Head → Broad Haven → Bosherton Lily Pools), the area near Strumble Head lighthouse, and more of the coast at Ceibwr Bay.

The lack of any form of signal in our hut shaped our evenings. We played card games, listened to BBC 6Music Radio, and read paperbacks with mugs of hot chocolate at hand.

Patricia Lockwood — No One Is Talking About This (2021)

Sep 26, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize

Patricia Lockwood’s extraordinary debut novel No One Is Talking About This is a book about what it’s like to live a substantial portion of one’s life online, and about the ways in which the internet has changed the manner of our being in the world. It’s also a book about what it’s like to experience something revelatory and wonderful — and also tragic and painful — at the scale of one’s family life, and how such an experience can change one’s understanding of the world.

Lockwood is an exceptional writer. Her work in poetry has sharpened her ability to render in language both a moment and its emotional valence: an idea as well as a sense of the absurdity or profundity of it. This, coupled with an unerring eye for the perfect detail and a talent for conjuring crystalline metaphors, leaves the reader with the impression that she is uncannily able to tease out the very heart of an emotional knot – to lay its hidden truths bare as though they were obvious. And, whilst there is certainly narrative and incident, No One Is Talking About This is primarily a novel of tone and feeling. It is never less than captivating to watch Lockwood find and maintain that rarest pitch: a perfect harmony of humour, melancholy, and raw emotional vulnerability1. The pathos of No One Is Talking About This is exquisitely rendered – it is as saddening as it is laugh-out-loud funny, and often in the very same paragraph.

A lot of writing about life online falls short in one important respect or another. It is either ignorant of the realities of online discourse — content instead to rely on broad or outdated cliché — or it adopts an arch tone that seeks to elevate the protagonist (and hence the author and reader) above the participants. Lockwood’s prose, whilst certainly still knowing, is understanding and interested. She is enthusiastic about the myriad joys of participation in social networks, often employing ‘you’ & ‘we’ as indefinite pronouns when writing of actions her protagonist takes online. It’s a subtle, effective evocation of the eerie sense of simultaneous communality and anonymity that life online can engender. Later in the novel — after a shift has occurred in the protagonist’s perspective — the technique seems to take on an almost anthropological note, as though seeking to explain the otherwise mysterious actions of a culture aeons distant. In an interview with Guernica magazine, Lockwood frames her work in terms of the realist social novel:

It doesn’t seem that different to be translating your encounter with the Ted Cruz porn tweet than it does to be translating your encounter with a croissant breakfast in Paris after your balls have been shot off in the war. You are talking about eating something, drinking something, opening the newspaper, watching people pass. You are choosing either a fine or a coarse grain of description.

It’s interesting to look at No One Is Talking About This, with its melding of forms, as a retooling of the social novel for the present moment. There is a sense that some elements of the novel exist within a very specific and narrow window. (For how long will the average reader grok references to Harambe, for example?) But, this in itself is reflective of the ephemeral nature of life online. In an interview with Slate, Lockwood refers to the ‘boundedness’ of the novel as a form, as an important contrast to the endlessness of the internet. So, this is a novel that knows about Trump, but not about COVID-19. In years to come it may take on new life as a piece of historical reportage about what it was like to use the social internet, very specifically, in the period 2016-2019.

At the heart of the novel’s (kinda, sorta) diptych construction is the question of whether the forms of the social web allow for serious expression. In an interview with The London Review of Books, Lockwood considers the ways in which her novel examines the limitations of ‘a pre-received form’ of language that has come to characterise many of the internet’s social spaces. ‘As the forms become rigid, masks do appear’ she says of the manner in which the accepted forms of expression on social networks (in particular) limit how and what participants can express. No One Is Talking About This captures the sound and feeling of two great ice sheets butting up against one another: the sardonic, quixotic, ephemeral churn of the modern connected world; and the enormity and complexity of life’s events more widely. The attempt to say something important or deeply felt about one’s own life, running up against the predominant tones and forms of online spaces. As she phrases it in the aforementioned Guernica piece:

We do spend so much of our time online, putting things out there, trying to be funny or sound smart. It can be nice to put something up and say, “I have a big serious life thing on the other side of the screen, too.” My mom passed away last year, and I posted photos of her every so often as a reminder: She lived, this happened.

In the LRB interview, Lockwood says that whilst writing she thought often of a line in George Elliot’s Middlemarch:

If we had a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow and the squirrel’s heart beat, and we should die of that roar which lies on the other side of silence.

Thus, what she calls ‘the diffuse pain of the portal’ is that no one knows where their attention should be in any one moment. It is a place comprising (in the words of Bo Burnham) ‘a little bit of everything, all of the time’. No One Is Talking About This contrasts this against the focussing power of personal tragedy. The novel introduces us to a narrator who swims adroitly in the fast-flowing river of online life, before refocussing to encompass life offline: wider, more emotionally diverse, more implacably difficult.

No One Is Talking About This is a truly extraordinary accomplishment. It is a vital, timely novel that affords us the opportunity to ask important questions about the role of the internet in our lives.

In the Slate interview mentioned above, Lockwood (b. 1982) characterises herself as being ‘from the perfect internet generation, and you can put that in a pull quote because this is very important’. It may well be the case that I responded to this novel so strongly in part because I’m from that same micro-generation: a cohort of people who had a pre-internet childhood, for whom the advent of social networks came in their late adolescence or early adulthood. No One Is Talking About This encapsulates both what I love about the internet, and also many of the ways in which it frustrates, disappoints, and constrains us. The inability of the ubiquitous digital sphere — with its aversion to depth, seriousness, nuance, complexity, and raw human feeling — to cope with vital parts of our lives, deserves attention. That Lockwood has addressed it with a novel both hilarious and deeply moving is nothing short of masterful.

  1. Other works that have accomplished something similar include Miranda July’s debut novel The First Bad Man (2015), and Bo Burnham’s comedy special Inside (2021). I find it noteworthy that July & Burnham are both artists who work in multiple forms (as is Lockwood: poetry, memoir, novel), and whose work is interested in part in form itself. ↩︎

Kazuo Ishiguro — Klara and the Sun (2021)

Sep 19, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

Sir Kazuo Ishiguro is the only previous winner on this year’s Booker Prize longlist1, and I come to his novel — Klara and the Sun — in the week that it was cut from the running, having not made the shortlist. Nevertheless, it seems likely that this will be one of the most widely read of the current Booker crop, and it is a strong novel. In the final analysis, however, it didn’t shock me to find it missing from the shortlist, as I think it falls short of Ishiguro’s finest work in a couple of key ways.

In a 2015 interview with The Guardian, Kazuo Ishiguro is quoted as saying “I tend to write the same book over and over, or at least, I take the same subject I took last time out and refine it, or do a slightly different take on it.” The example that he offers for this is (his Booker Prize winning novel) The Remains of the Day (1989), which he refers to as a “remake” of Artist of the Floating World (1986). Ishiguro frames both novels, despite their distinct settings, as works about what it means to waste one’s life: be it professional, personal, or romantic.

Much of the commentary around Klara and the Sun has figured the novel as a kind of ‘remake’ of 2005’s Never Let Me Go (2005). Both books fall within the broad category of literary science fiction, and both have at their heart shared questions around humanity. In a 2008 interview for The Paris Review, Ishiguro said this of why he chose to use clones as the protagonists in Never Let Me Go:

One of the attractions about using clones is that it makes people ask immediately, What does it mean to be a human being? It’s a secular route to the Dostoyevskian question, What is a soul? 

Undoubtedly, he is asking similar questions with this new novel, and approaching the subject from a slightly different angle. In Klara and the Sun the narration is from the perspective of the titular character, who is an artificial consciousness in a mechanical body2. Klara’s voice, as narrator, is pleasant and even, though the reader becomes increasingly aware of the ways in which she sees the world differently from those around her. I was reminded, in places, of Mark Haddon’s The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time (2003), which is narrated by a neurodiverse boy, whose perception of the world shapes the text to a large extent.

With novels in this mode it becomes the reader’s task to parse some of what is happening through the filter of how the narrator is experiencing it. In Klara’s case, we learn some of the peculiarities of how her vision works; we find that she is fond of specifics (particularly around things like measured dimensions and age); and we slowly grow accustomed to the fact that there are significant gaps in her understanding of the world. This form of narration is something of a double-edged sword in Klara and the Sun. It was certainly interesting to experience the world through a different lens, and to see how Klara perceives the places, people, and circumstances with which she comes into contact. However, increasingly I felt the absence of a dependable baseline of experience against which to make comparison. Unlike Haddon’s novel, for example, which is set in a recognisable turn-of-the-millennium Wiltshire, the reader necessarily cannot come to Ishiguro’s novel with any prior knowledge. This is a world of Artificial Friends and children who are ‘lifted’; the reader’s wish to understand the intricacies of these things is often frustrated by either the narrator’s ignorance of them, her misunderstanding of them, or her lack of interest in them.

When an author chooses to present a unique world in first-person perspective, there will always be the question of how much explanatory work the narrator is expected to perform. It is a characteristic of many pure fantasy novels, for instance, that a first-person narrator is burdened not only with telling their own story, but also with explaining the nuances of a peculiar world to the reader. The opposite, as employed by Ishiguro here, is to have a narrator unaware (or uninterested) in their role as tour guide, who leaves the reader largely in the dark as to how the world of the novel functions. It becomes part of the work of reading the novel, in these cases, to piece together the concrete particulars of the book’s world. It will likely be a matter of individual readers’ tastes as to how well they feel this is handled in Klara and the Sun. To my mind Ishiguro is operating a couple of steps beyond a level of obscurity that could have provided a richer experience. In the aforementioned Paris Review piece, Ishiguro says this of his writing style:

Most writers have certain things that they decide quite consciously, and other things they decide less consciously. In my case, the choice of narrator and setting are deliberate. You do have to choose a setting with great care, because with a setting come all kinds of emotional and historical reverberations.

By passing a world necessarily foreign to the reader through the somewhat distorted lens of Klara’s perception, I felt as though Ishiguro had deprived us of the means by which to truly know the world of his novel.

I also felt an uneasy tension in the construction and tone of the narrative. It is as though Ishiguro is not wholly decided as to whether or not the novel is to be read as allegory3.

One particular plot beat, for example, has an almost fairytale-like neatness. A character is conspicuously present who happens to possess the specialist knowledge required to effectively sabotage a particular machine. To compound this, the manner of sabotage happens to require a ‘special liquid’ which would be difficult to obtain were it not for the fact that it is also contained within the workings of Klara’s mechanical body. It is as though Ishiguro is too invested in furthering particular threads of plot, to worry about whether the action feels at all likely within the frame of his story.

Likewise, there is an irksome disparity between the function that some of the novel’s human characters ultimately wish for Klara to perform, and the reader’s clear understanding that she will not be capable of it. This is an instance in which the reader possesses greater clarity about Klara’s inner life than any of the humans who surround her can. To them, her simulacrum of a human being is often near-perfect; they do not know that her grasp of spatial awareness is so poor that she believes the Sun goes to rest at night in a particular building behind which it sets. When the novel raises questions about the distance between a human girl and an approximation of a human girl, it might frustrate the reader – who alone knows that Klara believes all the pollution in the world to be caused by one machine – that some characters in the novel believe it to be a negligible, bridgeable gap4.

The Nobel Prize in Literature is awarded for a body of work, with particular reason given for why the recipient was chosen. In Ishiguro’s case, when he was awarded the 2017 Prize, the Academy said that he has ‘in novels of great emotional force… uncovered the abyss beneath our illusory sense of connection with the world’. It is certainly possible to see this latest novel — his first since having been awarded the Nobel Prize — as a continuation of that project. And it is certainly a fascinating, immensely readable entry in that discourse.

Much of the above may read as though I did not enjoy Klara and the Sun, and that is not at all the case. Ishiguro is a masterful writer, with a deceptively simple prose style, and he is able to sustain the reader’s interest paragraph-to-paragraph and chapter-to-chapter with admirable ease. My complaints largely amount to subjective arguments about stylistic choices, and it is quite possible they may prove to be peculiarities of my own reading. It may well be the case that an approach to the novel that took it primarily as allegorical would find it all the more satisfying.

Towards the end of the book, after an indistinct passage of years has passed, there is a scene in which a roboticist explains to Klara (and thus the reader) that developments in artificial consciousness have outstripped human understanding. In turn, this has led to fear amongst people about the growing capabilities of non-biological minds.

They’re afraid because they can’t follow what’s going on inside any more. They can see what you do. They accept that your decisions, your recommendations, are sound and dependable, almost always correct. But they don’t like not knowing how you arrive at them.

Ironically, I found Klara and the Sun to be a very enjoyable and tenderly composed novel, which was somewhat at odds with its depiction of the functioning of its narrator’s artificial consciousness.

  1. Alongside Rachel Cusk and Richard Powers, he is one of three previous nominees. ↩︎

  2. A great deal of caution is required when discussing books in this genre space, to avoid using terms that may have specific connotations within the world of the novel. We might think of Klara, broadly, as an Artificial Intelligence, or say that she is an android, but these are not terms that the novel employs, and their absence is evidently a choice on the author’s part. ↩︎

  3. Likewise, there are certainly threads of the text that could be read as religious commentary; the intent, however, is not made explicit. ↩︎

  4. Consider, by way of comparison, Steven Spielberg’s 2001 film A.I. Artificial Intelligence, which raises this same question, but profits from the viewer’s comparatively less-direct access to the workings of an artificial consciousness. ↩︎

Karen Jennings — An Island (2021)

Sep 12, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

This is the sixth novel I’ve read as part of the 2021 Booker Prize longlist marathon, and the first that has not been a pleasant reading experience. That isn’t intended in an entirely pejorative sense, since Karen Jennings is certainly aiming – with some elements of An Island – to make the reader uncomfortable.

The narrative moves back and forth between an undated present and past in the life of its protagonist: Samuel. In doing so, the novel gives a wider picture of the misery and loss he has endured before ending up alone on a desolate island where he serves as lighthouse keeper. When the introduction of an unnamed man breaks decades of Samuel’s solitude, the reader comes to realise that his presence represents not just a dramatic change in Samuel’s life, but an opportunity to atone for some mistakes of his past.

John Donne’s ‘Meditation XVII’, to which the title of Karen Jennings’s novel can’t help but allude, is an expression of common humanity, in which Donne expresses the human condition in terms of shared suffering:

No man is an island entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main; if a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were, as well as any manner of thy friends or of thine own were; any man’s death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind. And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

It is certainly open to the charge of being morbid, but it is ultimately a hopeful work that revels in the universality of the human experience, including that of mortal death:

all mankind is of one author, and is one volume; when one man dies, one chapter is not torn out of the book, but translated into a better language

By contrast, I found An Island to be an unrelentingly pessimistic work, such that it leaves the reader feeling that it has nothing much to say. The most significant difference, I found, was a complete absence of faith in Jennings’s novel.

The locus of faith in Donne’s work is in the Christian God — Donne was, after all, an Anglican priest at the time of composing Devotions upon Emergent Occasions (1623) — but An Island also calls to mind the works of staunch atheist Samuel Beckett. In plays such as Waiting for Godot (1952) and Endgame (1957), Beckett has pairs of characters marooned in unforgiving environs, with little hope for the future. In these works — though the characters may be loathe to admit it — faith is found in the human spirit’s endurance, and the stubborn will to survive. Despite stark settings and pitch dark subjects, these are plays of humour that find warmth in the natures of their characters, and in their interactions. An Island, by contrast, seemed to me entirely cynical. It lacks any sense whatsoever of a universal order, but it also refuses to replace it with any sense of faith in its characters’ humanity, or in humanity generally.

The scope of the narrative, for instance, encompasses several eras of governance for its unnamed country. A revolution for independence replaces a colonial power with a President; the President is later overthrown in favour of a Dictator, and so on. Throughout, there are physical changes to some parts of the unnamed city, but the lives of the people barely change, and the slums do not improve, they only grow in size. Likewise, the novel has no faith in the power of people, or political activism, to engender meaningful change. Any sense of hope that a character experiences is quickly undercut by another, promising that it is futile:

The woman smiled, but the man said, “It was like this for us too, uncle. I’m sorry to tell you that. We were exactly like you.”
Samuel’s father laughed. “No, my friend, that isn’t possible. This is a free and democratic country. We’re independent, we have it all now. There will be no problems here. Your country did it the wrong way, you made mistakes.”
“Wait, uncle. You will see.” (p74)

And, when Samuel is moved to directly participate in frustrating for change, he too is quickly disillusioned:

The march could not be stopped. Not this tide of men and women who would no longer be told how to live. They had given up fear. They knew only strength.
Only afterwards, in the first interrogation room, did he learn that the march had been poorly attended, with little more than two thousand people participating. The event had barely disrupted the peace, and though hundreds had died and many more were arrested, it had made no impact at all. (p94)

Just as the works of groups are depicted as ineffectual, so the novel also has no faith in the ability of individuals to meaningfully change. Towards the end of the book, Jennings has reduced her elderly protagonist to little more than paranoia and base impulse:

He thought only of that word he had spoken down in the stone hut: violence – though now he uttered another world altogether, “Mine.” He stood up from where he had been kneeling. And again, “Mine” as he grabbed the knife out of the man’s hand. “Mine, mine, mine!” (p98)

The act of violence on which the novel ends is but the latest in a depressing, predictable sequence. It serves as but one more example in the novel of violence rendered in response to violence, and accomplishing nothing.

One might expect that in a novel so pessimistic about humanity, notes of optimism might be found in the depiction of nature. Instead, the natural world is often shown in An Island not as a force for rejuvenation, but as an adversary to be guarded against. Often, unsurprisingly in the world of the novel, this requires some form of violence:

he manipulated the weed with lit matches, watching it twist and shrivel, not stopping until he was certain enough damage had been done that it would never grow again. (p15)

At best, nature is sometimes shown to hold the power of erasure; for the most part, like the man-made change of the novel, much of what the natural world offers is bad and getting worse. A late scene depicts what at first seems to be a miraculous natural event: the annual arrival of giant crabs to the island. Quickly, however, the beauty of the event is undermined. The crabs (just like the island’s hens) attack one another, before the humans also attack the crabs. Next the reader is told of how precipitously the crab populations have declined, and how the small crabs that remain taste comparatively awful. If the sequence fails to depress, it is only because by this point in the novel the reader has likely been numbed into expecting nothing else.

Much of the above may have been more palatable to me, had I felt that the novel had something to say about a specific time, place, or culture. Instead, I felt that Jennings’s choice to make her novel purely an allegory robbed it of any chance of making meaningful political statements. Take, for example, this exchange, which is typical of the book’s political discourse:

“But you don’t agree with the idea of fighting against tyranny? You support the Dictator?” asked Big Ro.
“No, I’m not saying that. I know about opposing power. My father was amongst those who fought for independence.” (pp78-79)

Whom among us would support ‘the Dictator’? What does it mean to ‘oppose power’, or ‘fight for independence’? The novel is so determined to remain entirely allegorical that it absolutely refuses to be specific about any of these matters. Samuel’s political awakening is also rendered in similarly cursory terms:

They went to regular meetings, passed worn paperbacks between them in which they read theories of how to create a better world and life. They recited quotes from the texts, argued over words and phrases. At the meetings they rose, made speeches. (p91)

In an interview for LitNet, Jennings explicitly frames her responsibility as a novelist so as to exclude the need to answer any of the questions she poses:

My job as a writer is to hold a mirror up to these realities, but it is not within my abilities to suggest solutions.

The problem is that, so foggy and blurred is the mirror, that nothing can be seen of the ‘realities’ but the vaguest of outlines. Does the reader agree, in principle, that it is right to ‘oppose tyranny’? Regardless of the answer, the novel suggests, nothing will really change.

In another interview, this one with the Johannesburg Review of Books, Jennings discusses the difficulties she faced in writing An Island:

There was so much that was difficult about it. Firstly, trying to write a sensitive and nuanced book about a very complex set of topics—to do it without being heavy handed or reductive. Secondly, to write a readable, compelling story in which basically nothing happens!

To the first point, I found An Island to be too steeped in the vagaries of allegory to have anything insightful to say about either the political realities of post-colonialism, or the manner in which living in such circumstances might shape a person. And, as to the second point, I’m not convinced Jennings has succeeded there either. Paragraph-to-paragraph I enjoyed her writing well enough, but the relative slightness of the story, paired with its unrelenting cynicism, made the book feel increasingly like a chore as it progressed.

Unfortunately, the context in which I read An Island — as part of a Booker Prize longlist marathon — also makes for comparisons from which it does not profit. There is Anuk Arudpragasam’s A Passage North, which is more thoughtful and more grounded in its depiction of a country shaped by a history of conflict. And there is even a short section of Maggie Shipstead’s Great Circle that takes place on a secluded island, and which contains more deft character work than the entirety of Jennings’s novel.

Sep 11, 2021
Sep 6, 2021

Sunjeev Sahota — China Room (2021)

Sep 5, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope.

— Measure For Measure, Act III Scene i

Sunjeev Sahota is a British writer of Indian heritage, who was previously shortlisted for the Booker Prize in 2015, with his second novel: The Year of Runaways. That novel dealt with the lives of Indian immigrant workers in England, and followed Sahota’s first novel — Ours Are the Streets (2011) — which told the story of a British Pakistani’s radicalisation towards a terrorist act. China Room continues this examination of the topics of race, and entrapment within societal structures, but Sahota’s approach here is somewhat different.

The basic structure of China Room is an interweaving of two narratives separated by ~70 years, and three familial generations. Mehar Kaur lives on a farm in 1920s India, where she has been married to one of three brothers – though she does not know which.
